description.romaji: Expresses actions or states which regularly take place/exist or will take place/exist. The auxiliary masu makes the tone of speech polite.
description.kanji: Expresses actions or states which regularly take place/exist or will take place/exist. The auxiliary ます makes the tone of speech polite.

examples.romaji: Tomu wa mainichi toshokan e ikimasu.
examples.kanji: トムは 毎[まい]日[にち]図[と]書[しょ]館[かん]へ行[い]きます。
examples.translation: Tom goes to the library every day.

examples.romaji: Ashita Tanaka-san wa kimasen.
examples.kanji: 明日[あした]田[た]中[なか]さんは来[き]ません。
examples.translation: Miss Tanaka won't come tomorrow.

examples.romaji: Chichi wa sakki made koko ni imashita.
examples.kanji: 父[ちち]はさっきまでここにいました。
examples.translation: My father was here a while ago.

examples.romaji: Sumisu-san wa kinō gorufu o shimasen deshita.
examples.kanji: スミスさんは 昨日[きのう]ゴルフをしませんでした。
examples.translation: Mr. Smith did not play golf yesterday.

description.romaji: Expresses the first person's volition, invitation or suggestion.
description.kanji: Expresses the first person's volition, invitation or suggestion.

examples.romaji: Watashi ga tetsudaimashō.
examples.kanji: 私[わたし]が手[て]伝[つだ]いましょう。
examples.translation: I will help you.

examples.romaji: Kono dēta wa watashi-tachi ga shirabemashō.
examples.kanji: このデータは 私[わたし]達[たち]が調[しら]べましょう。
examples.translation: We will check this data.

examples.romaji: Ano heya de benkyō shimashō.
examples.kanji: あの 部[へ]屋[や]で勉[べん]強[きょう]しましょう。
examples.translation: Let's study in that room.

conjugation.kanji: Vconj + ましょうか・ませんか

description.romaji: Expresses a first person invitation or suggestion in the form of a question. The negative question masen ka is more polite than mashō ka.
description.kanji: Expresses a first person invitation or suggestion in the form of a question. The negative question ませんか is more polite than ましょうか.

examples.romaji: O-cha demo nomimashō ka.
examples.kanji: お 茶[ちゃ]でも飲[の]みましょうか。
examples.translation: Shall we drink tea or something?

examples.romaji: Mado o akemashō ka.
examples.kanji: 窓[まど]を開[あ]けましょうか。
examples.translation: Shall I open the window?

examples.romaji: Hara-san o pātī ni shōtai shimasen ka.
examples.kanji: 原[はら]さんをパーティーに招[しょう]待[たい]しませんか。
examples.translation: Wouldn't you (like to) invite Miss Hara to the party?

description.romaji: Expresses a plain imperative, used, for example, by teachers or parents to their students or children.
description.kanji: Expresses a plain imperative, used, for example, by teachers or parents to their students or children.

examples.romaji: Soto de asobinasai.
examples.kanji: 外[そと]で遊[あそ]びなさい。
examples.translation: Play outside.

examples.romaji: Nihongo de kotaenasai.
examples.kanji: 日[に]本[ほん]語[ご]で答[こた]えなさい。
examples.translation: Answer in Japanese.

examples.romaji: Kanji o nando mo renshū shinasai.
examples.kanji: 漢[かん]字[じ]を 何[なん]度[ど]も練[れん]習[しゅう]しなさい。
examples.translation: Practice kanji many times.

description.romaji: Expresses a polite imperative to superiors or customers.
description.kanji: Expresses a polite imperative to superiors or customers.

examples.romaji: Sanji made ni o-kaeri kudasai.
examples.kanji: 三[さん]時[じ]までにお帰[かえ]りください。
examples.translation: Would you please return by three o'clock.

footnotes.romaji: Note: Some verbs also use special polite alternative, e.g. miru (look) → Go-ran kudasai. (Would you please look.); iku/kuru (go/come) → Oide kudasai. (Would you please go/come.). For suru-verbs, the following polite imperative form is used: e.g. setsumei suru (explain) → Go-setsumei kudasai. (Would you please explain.). Normally, the polite prefix o is attached to Japanese verbs and go to suru-verbs of Chinese origin.
footnotes.kanji: Note: Some verbs also use special polite alternative, e.g. 見[み]る (look) → ご 覧[らん]ください。 (Would you please look.); 行[い]く・ 来[く]る (go/come) → おいでください。 (Would you please go/come.). For する-verbs, the following polite imperative form is used: e.g. 説[せつ]明[めい] (explain) → ご 説[せつ]明[めい]ください。 (Would you please explain.). Normally, the polite prefix お is attached to Japanese verbs and ご to する-verbs of Chinese origin.

examples.romaji: Dōzo o-kake kudasai.
examples.kanji: どうぞおかけください。
examples.translation: Would you please sit down.

conjugation.kanji: お + Vconj + します・いたします

description.romaji: Expresses the speaker's volition in the humble style. The verb itasu is the humble equivalent of suru.
description.kanji: Expresses the speaker's volition in the humble style. The verb いたす is the humble equivalent of する.

examples.romaji: Robī de o-machi shimasu/itashimasu.
examples.kanji: ロビーでお待[ま]ちします・いたします。
examples.translation: I'll wait for you in the lobby.

footnotes.romaji: Note: Some verbs use special humble words, e.g. iku/kuru (go/come) → mairimasu. (I'll go/come.); taberu/nomu (eat/drink) → itadakimasu. (I'll eat/drink.). For suru-verbs, the following humble form is used: e.g. renraku suru (contact) → Go-renraku itashimasu. (I'll contact you.).
footnotes.kanji: Note: Some verbs use special humble words, e.g. 行[い]く・ 来[く]る (go/come) → 参[まい]ります。 (I'll go/come.); 食[た]べる・ 飲[の]む (eat/drink) → いただきます。 (I'll eat/drink.). For する-verbs, the following humble form is used: e.g. 連[れん]絡[らく]する (contact) → ご 連[れん]絡[らく]いたします (I'll contact you.).

examples.romaji: Shinamono wa ashita o-todoke shimasu/itashimasu.
examples.kanji: 品[しな]物[もの]は 明日[あした]お届[とど]けします・いたします。
examples.translation: We'll deliver the article tomorrow.

description.romaji: Expresses actions in succession by linking two or more verbs.
description.kanji: Expresses actions in succession by linking two or more verbs.

examples.romaji: Maiasa kōhī o nomi, hachiji ni ie o demasu.
examples.kanji: 毎[まい]朝[あさ]コーヒーを飲[の]み、 八[はち]時[じ]に 家[いえ]を出[で]ます。
examples.translation: Every morning I drink coffee and leave my house at eight o'clock.

examples.romaji: Rokuji ni oki, ha o migaki, shawā o abimashita.
examples.kanji: 六[ろく]時[じ]に起[お]き、 歯[は]を磨[みが]き、シャワーを浴[あ]びました。
examples.translation: I got up at six o'clock, brushed my teeth and took a shower.

examples.romaji: Kuruma ga koshō shi, kaigi ni okuremashita.
examples.kanji: 車[くるま]が故[こ]障[しょう]し、 会[かい]議[ぎ]に遅[おく]れました。
examples.translation: My car broke down and I was late for the meeting.

description.romaji: Used as a noun by itself. Desu may be added to adjectives to make the speech polite.
description.kanji: Used as a noun by itself. です may be added to adjectives to make the speech polite.

examples.romaji: Doi-sensei no hanashi wa itsumo omoshiroi (desu).
examples.kanji: 土[ど]井[い]先[せん]生[せい]の話[はなし]はいつも 面[おも]白[しろ]い（です）。
examples.translation: Prof. Doi's talk is always interesting.

examples.romaji: Kono shōhin wa mōke ga oi (desu).
examples.kanji: この 商[しょう]品[ひん]はもうけが 多[おお]い（です）。
examples.translation: These goods bring in a large profit.

description.romaji: Expresses purpose when a person moves from one place to another. Used only with motion verbs such as iku (go), kuru (come), kaeru (return), hairu (enter), and deru (leave).
description.kanji: Expresses purpose when a person moves from one place to another. Used only with motion verbs such as 行[い]く (go), 来[く]る (come), 帰[かえ]る (return), 入[はい]る (enter), and 出[で]る (leave).

examples.romaji: Kusuri o kai ni mise ni hairimashita.
examples.kanji: 薬[くすり]を買[か]いに 店[みせ]に 入[はい]りました。
examples.translation: I entered a store to buy medicine.

examples.romaji: Hayashi-san wa kodomo o mukae ni eki e ikimasu.
examples.kanji: 林[はやし]さんは 子[こ]供[ども]を迎[むか]えに 駅[えき]へ 行[い]きます。
examples.translation: Mrs. Hayashi is going to the station to pick up her child.

examples.romaji: Jimu wa Nihongo o benkyō shi ni Nihon e kimashita.
examples.kanji: ジムは 日[に]本[ほん]語[ご]を勉[べん]強[きょう]し日[に]本[ほん]へ 来[き]ました。
examples.translation: Jim came to Japan to study Japanese.

description.romaji: Expresses simultaneous actions performed by one subject.
description.kanji: Expresses simultaneous actions performed by one subject.

examples.romaji: Miki-san wa tabako o suinagara shigoto o shimasu.
examples.kanji: 三[み]木[き]さんはたばこを吸[す]いながら 仕[し]事[ごと]をします。
examples.translation: Mr. Miki works while smoking.

examples.romaji: Akiko-san wa piano hikinagara utaimashita.
examples.kanji: 秋[あき] 子[こ]さんはピアノを弾[ひ]きながら 歌[うた]いました。
examples.translation: Akiko sang while playing the piano.

examples.romaji: Unten shinagara ongaku o kikimasu.
examples.kanji: 運[うん]転[てん]しながら 音[おん]楽[がく]を 聞[き]きます。
examples.translation: I listen to music while driving.

description.romaji: Expresses a first and third person desire (tai and tagaru, respectively) to do something. Desu may be added to the auxiliary tai to make the speech polite.
description.kanji: Expresses a first and third person desire (たい and たがる, respectively) to do something. です may be added to the auxiliary たい to make the speech polite.

examples.romaji: Shizuka na tokoro ni sumitai (desu).
examples.kanji: 静[しず]かな 所[ところ]に住[す]みたい（です）。
examples.translation: I want to live in a quiet place.

examples.romaji: Kodomo wa terebi o mitagarimasu.
examples.kanji: 子[こ]供[ども]はテレビを見[み]たがります。
examples.translation: Children want to watch TV.

examples.romaji: Otōto wa Amerika no daigaku ni nyūgaku shitagarimashita.
examples.kanji: 弟[おとうと]はアメリカの 大[だい]学[がく]に入[にゅう]学[がく]したがりました。
examples.translation: My younger brother wanted to enter an American college.

description.romaji: Expresses the speaker's conjecture based on what he sees or feels. The copula da may be replaced by desu to make the speech polite.
description.kanji: Expresses the speaker's conjecture based on what he sees or feels. The copula だ may be replaced by です to make the speech polite.

examples.romaji: Ame ga furi sō da.
examples.kanji: 雨[あめ]が降[ふ]りそうだ。
examples.translation: It looks like it will rain.

examples.romaji: Kaze de ki ga taore sō da.
examples.kanji: 風[かぜ]で 木[き]が倒[たお]れそうだ。
examples.translation: It looks like the tree will fall down because of the wind.

examples.romaji: Ono-san wa chikai uchi ni intai shisō desu.
examples.kanji: 小[お]野[の]さんは 近[ちか]いうちに引[いん] 退[たい]しそうです。
examples.translation: It looks like Mr. Ono will retire in the near future.

description.romaji: Creates compound nouns.
description.kanji: Creates compound nouns.

examples.romaji: nomimono (drink), tabemono (food), kaimono (shopping), yomimono (reading material), wasuremono (a thing left behind)
examples.kanji: 飲[の]み物[もの] (drink), 食[た]べ物[もの] (food), 買[か]い物[もの] (shopping), 読[よ]み物[もの] (reading material), 忘[わす]れ物[もの] (a thing left behind)

examples.romaji: tsukurikata (how to make), tsukaikata (usage), oyogikata (a way of swimming), oshiekata (teaching method), shikata (how to do)
examples.kanji: 作[つく]り方[かた] (how to make), 使[つか]い方[かた] (usage), 泳[およ]ぎ方[かた] (a way of swimming), 教[おし]え方[かた] (teaching method), 仕[し]方[かた] (how to do)

conjugation.kanji: Vconj + 始[はじ]める・ 終[お]わる

description.romaji: Vconj hajimeru/owaru are compound verbs. The verbs hajimeru (begin) and owaru (finish) are used as auxiliaries. Other verbs often used as auxiliaries are tsuzukeru (continue), wasureru (forget), naosu (correct), and sugiru (do/be in excess), as shown in Example 3.
description.kanji: Vconj 始[はじ]める・ 終[お]わる are compound verbs. The verbs 始[はじ]める (begin) and 終[お]わる (finish) are used as auxiliaries. Other verbs often used as auxiliaries are 続[つづ]ける (continue), 忘[わす]れる (forget), 直[なお]す (correct), and すぎる (do/be in excess), as shown in Example 3.

examples.romaji: Yuki ga furihajimemashita.
examples.kanji: 雪[ゆき]が降[ふ]り始[はじ]めました。
examples.translation: It began to snow.

examples.romaji: Yatto tabeowarimashita.
examples.kanji: やっと食[た]べ終[お]わりました。
examples.translation: I finally finished eating my meal.

examples.romaji: yomitsuzukeru
examples.kanji: 読[よ]み続[つづ]ける
examples.translation: continue to read

examples.romaji: haraiwasureru
examples.kanji: 払[はら]い忘[わす]れる
examples.translation: forget to pay

examples.romaji: kakinaosu
examples.kanji: 書[か]き直[なお]す
examples.translation: rewrite

examples.romaji: kyōsō shisugiru
examples.kanji: 競[きょう]争[そう]しすぎる
examples.translation: compete in excess

description.romaji: Expresses actions or states which regularly take place/exist or will take place/exist. This form is used for the plain style.
description.kanji: Expresses actions or states which regularly take place/exist or will take place/exist. This form is used for the plain style.

examples.romaji: Asoko ni hon'ya ga aru.
examples.kanji: あそこに 本[ほん]屋[や]がある。
examples.translation: There is a bookstore over there.

examples.romaji: Watashi wa maiasa rokuji ni okiru.
examples.kanji: 私[わたし]は 毎[まい]朝[あさ]六[ろく]時[じ]に起[お]きる。
examples.translation: I get up at six o'clock every morning.

examples.romaji: Tomu wa tokidoki toshokan de benkyō suru.
examples.kanji: トムは 時[とき]々[どき]図[と]書[しょ]館[かん]で勉[べん]強[きょう]する。
examples.translation: Sometimes Tom studies at the library.

description.romaji: Expresses a person's intention.Tsumori is a pseudo noun (never used independently) usually followed by a copula, da/datta (plain) or desu/deshita (polite).
description.kanji: Expresses a person's intention.つもり is a pseudo noun (never used independently) usually followed by a copula, だ・だった (plain) or です・でした (polite).

examples.romaji: Ie o uru tsumori da.
examples.kanji: 家[いえ]を売[う]るつもりだ。
examples.translation: I intend to sell my house.

examples.romaji: Kare wa gakkō o yameru tsumori desu.
examples.kanji: 彼[かれ]は 学[がっ]校[こう]を辞[や]めるつもりです。
examples.translation: He intends to quit school.

examples.romaji: Kaigi ni shusseki suru tsumori datta.
examples.kanji: 会[かい]議[ぎ]に出[しゅっ]席[せき]するつもりだった。
examples.translation: I intended to attend the meeting.

description.romaji: Expresses the speaker's expectation that something will take place/took place. Hazu is a pseudo noun usually followed by a copula.
description.kanji: Expresses the speaker's expectation that something will take place/took place. はず is a pseudo noun usually followed by a copula.

examples.romaji: Kono kisoku wa kawaru hazu da.
examples.kanji: この 規[き]則[そく]は変[か]わるはずだ。
examples.translation: It is expected that this regulation will change.

examples.romaji: Kono machi no jinkō wa fueru hazu desu.
examples.kanji: この 町[まち]の 人[じん]口[こう]は増[ふ]えるはずです。
examples.translation: The population of this town is expected to increase.

examples.romaji: Ano ken wa Ono-san ga chōsa suru hazu deshita.
examples.kanji: あの 件[けん]は 小[お]野[の]さんが調[ちょう]査[さ]するはずでした。
examples.translation: As for that matter, we expected that Mr. Ono would investigate it.

description.romaji: Expresses the speaker's conjecture. Darō, which is the presumptive form of the copula da, is used as an auxiliary. Deshō may be used for the polite style.
description.kanji: Expresses the speaker's conjecture. だろう, which is the presumptive form of the copula だ, is used as an auxiliary. でしょう may be used for the polite style.

examples.romaji: Gogo kaze ga fuku darō.
examples.kanji: 午[ご]後[ご]風[かぜ]が<em>吹[ふ]くだろう。
examples.translation: The wind will probably blow in the afternoon.

examples.romaji: Densha wa juppun hodo okureru darō.
examples.kanji: 電[でん]車[しゃ]は 十[じゅっ]分[ぷん]ほど遅[おく]れるだろう。
examples.translation: The train will probably be about ten minutes late.

examples.romaji: Kare wa jigyō ni seikō suru deshō.
examples.kanji: 彼[かれ]は 事[じ]業[ぎょう]に成[せい]功[こう]するでしょう。
examples.translation: He will probably succeed in his enterprise.

description.romaji: Expresses the speaker's speculation or guess. Kamoshiremasen is the polite style.
description.kanji: Expresses the speaker's speculation or guess. かもしれません is the polite style.

examples.romaji: Kono inu wa shinu kamoshirenai.
examples.kanji: この 犬[いぬ]は死[し]ぬかもしれない。
examples.translation: This dog might die.

examples.romaji: Onna no ko ga umareru kamoshiremasen.
examples.kanji: 女[おんな]の 子[こ]が生[う]まれるかもしれません。
examples.translation: A baby girl might be born (to her).

examples.romaji: Ane wa rainen kekkon suru kamoshiremasen.
examples.kanji: 姉[あね]は 来[らい]年[ねん]結[けっ]婚[こん]するかもしれません。
examples.translation: My older sister might marry next year.

description.romaji: Expresses the speaker's guess with confidence. Chigaiarimasen is the polite style.
description.kanji: Expresses the speaker's guess with confidence. ちがいありません is the polite style.

examples.romaji: Kodomo-tachi wa yorokobu ni chigainai.
examples.kanji: 子[こ]供[ども]達[たち]は喜[よろこ]ぶにちがいない。
examples.translation: There is no doubt that the children will be happy.

examples.romaji: Nihongo no gakusei ga fueru ni chigaiarimasen.
examples.kanji: 日[に]本[ほん]語[ご]の 学[がく]生[せい]が増[ふ]えるにちがいありません。
examples.translation: The (number of) students of Japanese will undoubtedly increase.

examples.romaji: Gijutsu wa shinpo suru ni chigaiarimasen.
examples.kanji: 技[ぎ]術[じゅつ]は進[しん]歩[ぽ]するにちがいありません。
examples.translation: There is no doubt that technology will make progress.

description.romaji: Both no and koto are nominalizers which make a verb into a gerund, or a clause into a noun phrase. No indicates concrete actions or events, while koto indicates abstract actions or events. No and koto are sometimes interchangeable (Example 3).
description.kanji: Both の and こと are nominalizers which make a verb into a gerund, or a clause into a noun phrase. の indicates concrete actions or events, while こと indicates abstract actions or events. の and こと are sometimes interchangeable (Example 3).

examples.romaji: Watashi wa otoko ga jitensha o nusumu no o mimashita.
examples.kanji: 私[わたし]は 男[おとこ]が 自[じ]転[てん]車[しゃ]を盗[ぬす]むのを 見[み]ました。
examples.translation: I saw a man stealing a bicycle.

examples.romaji: Miru koto wa shinjiru koto desu.
examples.kanji: 見[み]ることは信[しん]じることです。
examples.translation: Seeing is believing.

examples.romaji: Hara-san ga Furansu ni tenkin suru no/koto o kikimashita.
examples.kanji: 原[はら]さんがフランスに転[てん]勤[きん]するの・ことを 聞[き]きました。
examples.translation: I heard that Mr. Hara is going to be transferred to France.

conjugation.kanji: Vdic + ことが 出[で]来[き]る

description.romaji: Expresses potential and ability. This potential form is used in the wa-ga construction: A wa ~ koto ga dekiru. (A can do ~.)
description.kanji: Expresses potential and ability. This potential form is used in the は-が construction: A は～ことが出[で]来[き]る。 (A can do ~.)

examples.romaji: Kono shigoto wa Kida-san ni makasu koto ga dekiru.
examples.kanji: この 仕[し]事[ごと]は 木[き]田[だ]さんに任[まか]すことが 出[で]来[き]る。
examples.translation: We can leave this job up to Ms. Kida.

examples.romaji: Kodomo wa sugu kotoba o oboeru koto ga dekimasu.
examples.kanji: 子[こ]供[ども]はすぐ 言[こと]葉[ば]を覚[おぼ]えることが 出[で]来[き]ます。
examples.translation: Children can learn words quickly.

examples.romaji: Kono hon o chūmon suru koto ga dekimasu ka.
examples.kanji: この 本[ほん]を注[ちゅう]文[もん]することが 出[で]来[き]ますか。
examples.translation: Can I order this book?

description.romaji: Expresses actions or events that occur sometimes.
description.kanji: Expresses actions or events that occur sometimes.

examples.romaji: Yano-san wa enkai de you koto ga aru.
examples.kanji: 矢[や]野[の]さんは 宴[えん]会[かい]で酔[よ]うことがある。
examples.translation: There are times when Mr. Yano gets drunk at a banquet.

examples.romaji: Tsuyoi chīmu ga makeru koto ga arimasu.
examples.kanji: 強[つよ]いチームが負[ま]けることがあります。
examples.translation: There are times when a strong team is defeated (by a weak one).

examples.romaji: Tomodachi to ryokō suru koto ga aru.
examples.kanji: 友[とも]達[だち]と旅[りょ]行[こう]することがある。
examples.translation: There are times when I travel with my friends.

description.romaji: Expresses the speaker's decision to do something.
description.kanji: Expresses the speaker's decision to do something.

examples.romaji: Raigetsu Kyōto ni utsuru koto ni shimashita.
examples.kanji: 来[らい]月[げつ]京[きょう]都[と]に移[うつ]ることにしました。
examples.translation: I decided to move to Kyoto next month.

examples.romaji: Honbako wa koko ni naraberu koto ni suru.
examples.kanji: 本[ほん]箱[ばこ]はここに並[なら]べることにする。
examples.translation: I will put these bookcases side by side here.

examples.romaji: Maiasa sanpo suru koto ni shimasu.
examples.kanji: 毎[まい]朝[あさ]散[さん]歩[ぽ]することにします。
examples.translation: I'll make it a rule to take a walk every morning.

description.romaji: Expresses a decision made by others, rather than the speaker.
description.kanji: Expresses a decision made by others, rather than the speaker.

examples.romaji: Motto sensei o yatou koto ni naru darō.
examples.kanji: もっと 先[せん]生[せい]を雇[やと]うことになるだろう。
examples.translation: It will be decided that they will hire more teachers.

examples.romaji: Sagawa-san wa shiten ni tsutomeru koto ni narimasu.
examples.kanji: 佐[さ]川[がわ]さんは 支[し]店[てん]に勤[つと]めることになります。
examples.translation: It will be decided that Mr. Sagawa will work at a branch office.

examples.romaji: Honda-san ga tōronkai ni sanka suru koto ni narimashita.
examples.kanji: 本[ほん]田[だ]さんが 討[とう]論[ろん]会[かい]に参[さん]加[か]することになりました。
examples.translation: It has been decided that Miss Honda will participate in the debate.

description.romaji: Expresses an action which is about to take place. In this expression, tokoro means "state" or "time."
description.kanji: Expresses an action which is about to take place. In this expression, ところ means "state" or "time."

examples.romaji: Kuruma wa kado o magaru tokoro desu.
examples.kanji: 車[くるま]は 角[かど]を曲[ま]がるところです。
examples.translation: The car is just about to turn the corner.

examples.romaji: Akira wa ima neru tokoro da.
examples.kanji: 明[あきら]は 今[いま]寝[ね]るところだ。
examples.translation: Akira is just about to go to bed now.

examples.romaji: Densha wa shuppatsu suru tokoro desu.
examples.kanji: 電[でん]車[しゃ]は出[しゅっ]発[ぱつ]するところです。
examples.translation: The train is just about to depart.

description.romaji: Expresses a comparison between two actions. Hō is a pseudo noun.
description.kanji: Expresses a comparison between two actions. ほう is a pseudo noun.

examples.romaji: Katsu hō ga makeru yori ii.
examples.kanji: 勝[か]つほうが負[ま]けるよりいい。
examples.translation: Winning is better than losing.

examples.romaji: Kuruma wa koko ni tomeru yori asoko ni tomeru hō ga anzen desu.
examples.kanji: 車[くるま]はここに止[と]めるよりあそこに止[と]めるほうが 安[あん]全[ぜん]です。
examples.translation: It is safer to park the car here than (park) over there.

examples.romaji: Jibun de ryōri suru hō ga gaishoku suru yori tanoshii desu.
examples.kanji: 自[じ]分[ぶん]で料[りょう]理[り]するほうが外[がい]食[しょく]するより 楽[たの]しいです。
examples.translation: It is more enjoyable to cook myself than to dine out.

description.romaji: Expresses an action which is replaced by another action.
description.kanji: Expresses an action which is replaced by another action.

examples.romaji: Konban asobu kawari ni ashita yoku benkyō suru.
examples.kanji: 今[こん]晩[ばん]遊[あそ]ぶ代[か]わりに 明日[あした]よく 勉[べん]強[きょう]する。
examples.translation: I'll study hard tomorrow to make up for having fun tonight.

examples.romaji: Kotoba o oboeru kawari ni kanji o renshū shimasu.
examples.kanji: 言[こと]葉[ば]を覚[おぼ]える代[か]わりに 漢[かん]字[じ]を 練[れん]習[しゅう]します。
examples.translation: Instead of memorizing words, I'll practice kanji.

examples.romaji: Kaigi ni shusseki suru kawari ni repōto o teishutsu shimasu.
examples.kanji: 会[かい]議[ぎ]に出[しゅっ]席[せき]する代[か]わりにレポートを 提[てい]出[しゅつ]します。
examples.translation: Instead of attending the meeting, I'll submit the report.

description.romaji: Expresses a temporal relation between one action and another.
description.kanji: Expresses a temporal relation between one action and another.

examples.romaji: Kare wa tokidoki beru ga naru mae ni kyōshitsu o deru.
examples.kanji: 彼[かれ]は 時[とき]々[どき]ベルが鳴[な]る前[まえ]に 教[きょう]室[しつ]を 出[で]る。
examples.translation: Sometimes he leaves the classroom before the bell rings.

examples.romaji: Neru mae ni ha o migakimasu.
examples.kanji: 寝[ね]る前[まえ]に 歯[は]を 磨[みが]きます。
examples.translation: I brush my teeth before going to bed.

examples.romaji: Yoshū suru mae ni fukushū suru.
examples.kanji: 予[よ]習[しゅう]する前[まえ]に 復[ふく]習[しゅう]する。
examples.translation: I review (my lessons) before preparing my lessons (for tomorrow).

description.romaji: Expresses a temporal limit for an action.
description.kanji: Expresses a temporal limit for an action.

examples.romaji: Apāto ga aku made nikagetsu machimashita.
examples.kanji: アパートが空[あ]くまで 二[に]か 月[げつ]待[ま]ちました。
examples.translation: I waited two months until the apartment became vacant.

examples.romaji: Sora ga hareru made hoteru ni imashita.
examples.kanji: 空[そら]が晴[は]れるまでホテルにいました。
examples.translation: I stayed at the hotel until the sky cleared up.

examples.romaji: Jimu wa sotsugyō suru made yoku ganbarimashita.
examples.kanji: ジムは卒[そつ]業[ぎょう]するまでよく 頑[がん]張[ば]りました。
examples.translation: Jim held on well until he graduated.

description.romaji: Expresses a temporal limit for an action. It may be replaced by mae ni.
description.kanji: Expresses a temporal limit for an action. It may be replaced by 前[まえ]に.

examples.romaji: Hi ga shizumu made ni mokutekichi ni tsukitai.
examples.kanji: 日[ひ]が沈[しず]むまでに 目[もく]的[てき]地[ち]に 着[つ]きたい。
examples.translation: We want to reach our destination before the sun sets.

examples.romaji: Kare ga ryokō ni dekakeru made ni mō ichido aitai desu.
examples.kanji: 彼[かれ]が 旅[りょ]行[こう]に出[で]かけるまでにもう 一[いち]度[ど]会[あ]いたいです。
examples.translation: I want to see him once more before he leaves for his trip.

examples.romaji: Hikōki ga tōchaku suru made ni nijikan aru.
examples.kanji: 飛[ひ]行[こう]機[き]が到[とう]着[ちゃく]するまでに 二[に]時[じ]間[かん]ある。
examples.translation: It will be two hours before the airplane arrives.

description.romaji: Expresses the purpose of doing something.
description.kanji: Expresses the purpose of doing something.

examples.romaji: Kagu o hakobu noni torakku ga iru.
examples.kanji: 家[か]具[ぐ]を運[はこ]ぶのにトラックが 要[い]る。
examples.translation: We need a truck to transport the furniture.

examples.romaji: O-kane o azukeru noni ano ginkō ga ichiban ii desu.
examples.kanji: お 金[かね]を預[あず]けるのにあの 銀[ぎん]行[こう]が 一[いち]番[ばん]いいです。
examples.translation: That bank is the best one to deposit money in.

examples.romaji: Tsūkin suru noni chikatetsu o riyō shimasu.
examples.kanji: 通[つう]勤[きん]するのに 地[ち]下[か]鉄[てつ]を 利[り]用[よう]します。
examples.translation: I use the subway to commute to the office.

description.romaji: Expresses an action which is followed by a result contrary to expectation.
description.kanji: Expresses an action which is followed by a result contrary to expectation.

examples.romaji: Ichinichi ni nanmairu mo aruku noni tsukaremasen.
examples.kanji: 一[いち]日[にち]に 何[なん]マイルも歩[ある]くのに 疲[つか]れません。
examples.translation: Although I walk many miles a day, I don't get tired.

examples.romaji: Kanojo wa takusan taberu noni futorimasen.
examples.kanji: 彼[かの]女[じょ]はたくさん食[た]べるのに 太[ふと]りません。
examples.translation: Although she eats a lot, she doesn't get fat.

examples.romaji: Tomu wa doryoku suru noni seiseki ga agarimasen.
examples.kanji: トムは努[ど]力[りょく]するのに 成[せい]績[せき]が 上[あ]がりません。
examples.translation: Although Tom makes an effort, his grades do not go up.

description.romaji: Expresses a condition that brings about an automatic or unexpected result.
description.kanji: Expresses a condition that brings about an automatic or unexpected result.

examples.romaji: Beru o osu to doa ga akimashita.
examples.kanji: ベルを押[お]すとドアが 開[あ]きました。
examples.translation: When I pushed the bell, the door opened.

examples.romaji: O-kane o kazoeru to, nisen'en tarimasen deshita.
examples.kanji: お 金[かね]を数[かぞ]えると、 二[に]千[せん]円[えん]足[た]りませんでした。
examples.translation: When I counted the money, I was 2,000 yen short.

examples.romaji: Takusan chūmon suru to, waribiki ga aru.
examples.kanji: たくさん注[ちゅう]文[もん]すると、 割[わり]引[びき]がある。
examples.translation: If you order a lot, you can get a discount.

description.romaji: Expresses a supposition or condition. Since nara is the conditional form of the copula da, it requires a noun. Therefore, no is added to nominalize the verb, though this no is optional.
description.kanji: Expresses a supposition or condition. Since なら is the conditional form of the copula だ, it requires a noun. Therefore, の is added to nominalize the verb, though this の is optional.

examples.romaji: Ie o uru (no) nara, ima ga ii jiki da.
examples.kanji: 家[いえ]を売[う]る（の）なら、 今[いま]がいい 時[じ]期[き]だ。
examples.translation: If you are to sell the house, now is a good time.

examples.romaji: Konban soto de taberu (no) nara, doko ga ii desu ka.
examples.kanji: 今[こん]晩[ばん]外[そと]で食[た]べる（の）なら、どこがいいですか。
examples.translation: If we dine out tonight, where is a good place?

examples.romaji: Kenbutsu suru (no) nara, kankō-basu ga ii desu yo.
examples.kanji: 見[けん]物[ぶつ]する（の）なら、 観[かん]光[こう]バスがいいですよ。
examples.translation: If you go sightseeing, a tour bus would be good.

conjugation.translation: • "(I don't know/can't tell) when, what, etc."

description.romaji: Expresses a question embedded in a sentence. The particle is optional.
description.kanji: Expresses a question embedded in a sentence. The particle is optional.

examples.romaji: Nani ga okoru ka wakarimasen.
examples.kanji: 何[なに]が起[お]こるか 分[わ]かりません。
examples.translation: I can't tell what will happen.

examples.romaji: Dochira ga makeru ka wakarimasen.
examples.kanji: どちらが負[ま]けるか 分[わ]かりません。
examples.translation: Which one of them will lose, I can't tell.

examples.romaji: Ono-san ga itsu ryūgaku suru ka shirimasen.
examples.kanji: 小[お]野[の]さんがいつ留[りゅう]学[がく]するか 知[し]りません。
examples.translation: I don't know when Miss Ono will study abroad.

conjugation.translation: • "(I don't know/can't tell) whether or not"

description.romaji: Expresses a question embedded in a sentence.
description.kanji: Expresses a question embedded in a sentence.

examples.romaji: Sumisu-san ga Nihongo o hanasu ka dō ka shirimasen.
examples.kanji: スミスさんが 日[に]本[ほん]語[ご]を話[はな]すかどうか 知[し]りません。
examples.translation: I don't know whether Mr. Smith speaks Japanese or not.

examples.romaji: Pikunikku no hi o kaeru ka dō ka shirimasen.
examples.kanji: ピクニックの 日[ひ]を変[か]えるかどうか 知[し]りません。
examples.translation: I don't know whether they will change the date for the picnic or not.

examples.romaji: Kare ga atarashii kikai o hatsumei suru ka dō ka wakarimasen.
examples.kanji: 彼[かれ]が 新[あたら]しい 機[き]械[かい]を発[はつ]明[めい]するかどうか 分[わ]かりません。
examples.translation: I can't tell whether he will invent a new machine or not.

description.romaji: Expresses purpose.
description.kanji: Expresses purpose.

examples.romaji: Netsu ga sagaru yō ni asupirin o nominasai.
examples.kanji: 熱[ねつ]が下[さ]がるようにアスピリンを 飲[の]みなさい。
examples.translation: Take aspirin so that your fever goes down.

examples.romaji: Kare wa jōshi ga jibun no teian o mitomeru yō ni nesshin ni hanashimashita.
examples.kanji: 彼[かれ]は 上[じょう]司[し]が 自[じ]分[ぶん]の 提[てい]案[あん]を認[みと]めるように 熱[ねっ]心[しん]に 話[はな]しました。
examples.translation: He spoke eagerly so that his superior would approve his proposal.

examples.romaji: Sensei wa gakusei ga rikai suru yō ni yoku setsumei shimashita.
examples.kanji: 先[せん]生[せい]は 学[がく]生[せい]が理[り]解[かい]するようによく 説[せつ]明[めい]しました。
examples.translation: The teacher explained thoroughly so that the students would understand.

description.romaji: Expresses an indirect command. The verb iu may be replaced by other verbs such as tanomu (ask) or susumeru (recommend) to express requests or suggestions.
description.kanji: Expresses an indirect command. The verb 言[い]う may be replaced by other verbs such as 頼[たの]む (ask) or 勧[すす]める (recommend) to express requests or suggestions.

examples.romaji: Gakusei ni kabe ni posutā o haru yō ni iu.
examples.kanji: 学[がく]生[せい]に 壁[かべ]にポスターを張[は]るように 言[い]う。
examples.translation: I'll tell the students to put posters on the wall.

examples.romaji: Toda-san ni kaigi no jikan o tashikameru yō ni tanomimasu.
examples.kanji: 戸[と]田[だ]さんに 会[かい]議[ぎ]の 時[じ]間[かん]を確[たし]かめるように 頼[たの]みます。
examples.translation: I'll ask Miss Toda to confirm the meeting time.

examples.romaji: Buraun-san ni Kyōto de o-tera o hōmon suru yō ni susumemashita.
examples.kanji: ブラウンさんに 京[きょう]都[と]でお 寺[てら]を訪[ほう]問[もん]するように 勧[すす]めました。
examples.translation: I recommended to Mr. Brown that he visit temples in Kyoto.

description.romaji: Expresses a change that gradually takes place.
description.kanji: Expresses a change that gradually takes place.

examples.romaji: Akachan wa mō sugu warau yō ni naru.
examples.kanji: 赤[あか]ちゃんはもうすぐ笑[わら]うようになる。
examples.translation: The baby will soon reach the point where he will smile.

examples.romaji: Kodomo wa jibun de heya o katazukeru yō ni narimashita.
examples.kanji: 子[こ]供[ども]は 自[じ]分[ぶん]で 部[へ]屋[や]を片[かた]付[づ]けるようになりました。
examples.translation: My child has reached the point where she cleans up her room herself.

examples.romaji: Sono kōjō wa denki kigu o seisan suru yō ni narimashita.
examples.kanji: その 工[こう]場[じょう]は 電[でん]気[き]器[き]具[ぐ]を生[せい]産[さん]するようになりました。
examples.translation: The plant has reached the point where it produces electrical appliances.

description.romaji: Expresses a person's efforts to cause a change in behavior.
description.kanji: Expresses a person's efforts to cause a change in behavior.

examples.romaji: Shimekiri ni maniau yō ni suru.
examples.kanji: 締[し]め 切[き]りに間[ま]に 合[あ]うようにする。
examples.translation: I'll make sure that I'll be in time for the deadline.

examples.romaji: Rokuji ni mise o shimeru yō ni shinasai.
examples.kanji: 六[ろく]時[じ]に 店[みせ]を閉[し]めるようにしなさい。
examples.translation: Make sure that you close up the store at six o'clock.

examples.romaji: Kanojo wa maitsuki chokin suru yō ni shimashita.
examples.kanji: 彼[かの]女[じょ]は 毎[まい]月[つき]貯[ちょ]金[きん]するようにしました。
examples.translation: She made sure that she saved money every month.

description.romaji: Expresses a cause or a reason personally interpreted by the speaker. The dictionary form (plain style) is normally used in the subordinate clause. The masu form may also be used in the subordinate clause in very polite speech (Example 3).
description.kanji: Expresses a cause or a reason personally interpreted by the speaker. The dictionary form (plain style) is normally used in the subordinate clause. The ます form may also be used in the subordinate clause in very polite speech (Example 3).

examples.romaji: Parēdo ga tōru kara, mi ni ikimashō.
examples.kanji: パレードが通[とお]るから、 見[み]に 行[い]きましょう。
examples.translation: The parade will pass by, so let's go to see it.

examples.romaji: Umi ga mieru kara, kono heya o erabimashita.
examples.kanji: 海[うみ]が見[み]えるから、この 部[へ]屋[や]を 選[えら]びました。
examples.translation: I chose this room because I can see the ocean (from here).

examples.romaji: Ryōshin ga anshin suru/shimasu kara, maishū denwa shimasu.
examples.kanji: 両[りょう]親[しん]が安[あん]心[しん]する・しますから、 毎[まい]週[しゅう]電[でん]話[わ]します。
examples.translation: Because my parents feel relieved, I call them every week.

description.romaji: Expresses a cause or a reason presented more objectively without projecting the speaker's personal opinion. This node clause cannot be followed by a main clause involving the speaker's volition, opinion, command or invitation.
description.kanji: Expresses a cause or a reason presented more objectively without projecting the speaker's personal opinion. This ので clause cannot be followed by a main clause involving the speaker's volition, opinion, command or invitation.

examples.romaji: Ashita bōnasu o morau node, ureshii.
examples.kanji: 明日[あした]ボーナスをもらうので、 嬉[うれ]しい。
examples.translation: I'm happy, because I'll receive a bonus tomorrow.

examples.romaji: Kare wa asa hayaku okiru node, hayaku shukkin shimasu.
examples.kanji: 彼[かれ]は 朝[あさ]早[はや]く起[お]きるので、 早[はや]く 出[しゅっ]勤[きん]します。
examples.translation: Because he gets up early in the morning, he comes to work early.

examples.romaji: Yano-san ga nyūin suru node, watashi ga enkai ni deru koto ni narimashita.
examples.kanji: 矢[や]野[の]さんが入[にゅう]院[いん]するので、 私[わたし]が 宴[えん]会[かい]に 出[で]ることになりました。
examples.translation: Since Mr. Yano will be hospitalized, it's been decided that I will attend the banquet.

description.romaji: Expresses indirect quotations. The verb iu may be replaced by other verbs such as omou (think) or kiku (hear) to express what a person thinks or hears.
description.kanji: Expresses indirect quotations. The verb 言[い]う may be replaced by other verbs such as 思[おも]う (think) or 聞[き]く (hear) to express what a person thinks or hears.

examples.romaji: Abe-sensei wa kōgi wa sanji made ni sumu to iimashita.
examples.kanji: 阿[あ]部[べ]先[せん]生[せい]は 講[こう]義[ぎ]は 三[さん]時[じ]までに済[す]むと 言[い]いました。
examples.translation: Prof. Abe said that the lecture would end by three o'clock.

examples.romaji: Kare wa itsuka kokyō o tazuneru to omou.
examples.kanji: 彼[かれ]はいつか 故[こ]郷[きょう]を訪[たず]ねると 思[おも]う。
examples.translation: I think that he will visit his home town some day.

examples.romaji: Yamada-san ga atarashii kaisha o soshiki suru to kikimashita.
examples.kanji: 山[やま]田[だ]さんが 新[あたら]しい 会[かい]社[しゃ]を組[そ]織[しき]すると 聞[き]きました。
examples.translation: I heard that Mr. Yamada will set up a new company.

description.romaji: Expresses the speaker's conjecture based on some reliable information. Desu may be added to the auxiliary rashii to make the speech polite.
description.kanji: Expresses the speaker's conjecture based on some reliable information. です may be added to the auxiliary らしい to make the speech polite.

examples.romaji: Ekimae ni sūpā ga tatsu rashii (desu).
examples.kanji: 駅[えき]前[まえ]にスーパーが建[た]つらしい（です）。
examples.translation: It looks like a supermarket will be built in front of the station.

examples.romaji: Yukiko-san wa Kanada ryokō o akirameru rashii (desu).
examples.kanji: 雪[ゆき]子[こ]さんはカナダ 旅[りょ]行[こう]をあきらめるらしい（です）。
examples.translation: It seems that Yukiko will give up the (idea of) a Canadian trip.

examples.romaji: Ano kaisha wa tōsan suru rashii (desu).
examples.kanji: あの 会[かい]社[しゃ]は倒[とう]産[さん]するらしい（です）。
examples.translation: I heard that the company will go bankrupt.

conjugation.translation:
• "I hear that~"
  • "I heard that ~"
  • "People say that ~"

description.romaji: Expresses hearsay—what the speaker heard or information obtained indirectly.
description.kanji: Expresses hearsay—what the speaker heard or information obtained indirectly.

examples.romaji: Kare wa ofisu o Yokohama ni utsutsu sō da.
examples.kanji: 彼[かれ]はオフィスを 横[よこ]浜[はま]に移[うつ]すそうだ。
examples.translation: I heard that he will move his office to Yokohama.

examples.romaji: Doa ni keihōki o tsukeru sō desu.
examples.kanji: ドアに 警[けい]報[ほう]機[き]を付[つ]けるそうです。
examples.translation: I hear that they will put an alarm on the door.

examples.romaji: Yamada-san wa raishū atari taiin suru sō desu.
examples.kanji: 山[やま]田[だ]さんは 来[らい]週[しゅう]あたり退[たい]院[いん]するそうです。
examples.translation: People say that Mr. Yamada will be released from hospital some time next week.

description.romaji: Expresses uncertainty. Kashira is mostly used by women, while kana is principally used by men.
description.kanji: Expresses uncertainty. かしら is mostly used by women, while かな is principally used by men.

examples.romaji: Byōnin wa tasukaru kashira/kana.
examples.kanji: 病[びょう]人[にん]は助[たす]かるかしら・かな。
examples.translation: I wonder if the patient will be saved.

examples.romaji: Kare wa kurisumasu purezento ni nani o kureru kashira/kana.
examples.kanji: 彼[かれ]はクリスマスプレゼントに 何[なに]をくれるかしら・かな。
examples.translation: I wonder what he wil give me for a Christmas present.

examples.romaji: Tomu wa shiken ni gōgaku suru kashira/kana.
examples.kanji: トムは 試[し]験[けん]に合[ごう]格[がく]するかしら・かな。
examples.translation: I wonder if Tom will pass the examination.

description.romaji: Expresses prohibition and is used by men in very informal speech.
description.kanji: Expresses prohibition and is used by men in very informal speech.

examples.romaji: Kare no kotoba o utagaru na.
examples.kanji: 彼[かれ]の 言[こと]葉[ば]を疑[うたが]うな。
examples.translation: Don't doubt his words.

examples.romaji: Sono harigane o mageru na.
examples.kanji: その 針[はり]金[がね]を曲[ま]げるな。
examples.translation: Don't bend that wire.

examples.romaji: Anna otoko to giron suru na.
examples.kanji: あんな 男[おとこ]と議[ぎ]論[ろん]するな。
examples.translation: Don't argue with that kind of man.

description.romaji: Used as a modifier of the following noun, e.g. iku hito (persons who go); niji ni deru basu (the bus that leaves at two o'clock). Japanese does not have relative pronouns such as "who," "which," and "that."
description.kanji: Used as a modifier of the following noun, e.g. 行[い]く 人[ひと] (persons who go); 二[に]時[じ]に 出[で]るバス (the bus that leaves at two o'clock). Japanese does not have relative pronouns such as "who" "which" and "that."

examples.romaji: Kyō watashi ga au hito wa chichi no tomodachi da.
examples.kanji: 今日[きょう]私[わたし]が会[あ]う人[ひと]は 父[ちち]の 友[とも]達[だち]だ。
examples.translation: The person whom I'll meet today is my father's friend.

examples.romaji: Ogawa-sensei no kawari ni oshieru sensei wa Noda-sensei desu.
examples.kanji: 小[お]川[がわ]先[せん]生[せい]の 代[か]わりに教[おし]える先[せん]生[せい]は 野[の]田[だ]先[せん]生[せい]です。
examples.translation: The teacher who will teach in place of Prof. Ogawa is Prof. Noda.

examples.romaji: Kore wa shokuhin o kakō suru kikai desu.
examples.kanji: これは 食[しょく]品[ひん]を加[か]工[こう]する機[き]械[かい]です。
examples.translation: This is the machine that processes food.

description.romaji: Expresses the extent of an action or condition.
description.kanji: Expresses the extent of an action or condition.

examples.romaji: Kanojo wa byōki ni naru hodo yoku hataraku.
examples.kanji: 彼[かの]女[じょ]は 病[びょう]気[き]になるほどよく 働[はたら]く。
examples.translation: She works hard to the extent of becoming ill.

examples.romaji: Kono gēmu wa kodomo demo dekiru hodo kantan da.
examples.kanji: このゲームは 子[こ]供[ども]でも出[で]来[き]るほど 簡[かん]単[たん]だ。
examples.translation: This game is so simple that even a child can play it.

examples.romaji: Kare wa oya ga shinpai suru hodo sake o nomimasu.
examples.kanji: 彼[かれ]は 親[おや]が心[しん]配[ぱい]するほど 酒[さけ]を 飲[の]みます。
examples.translation: He drinks to the extent that his parents worry.

description.romaji: Expresses the only action left to do.
description.kanji: Expresses the only action left to do.

examples.romaji: Mō shinkyo ni utsuru bakari da.
examples.kanji: もう 新[しん]居[きょ]に移[うつ]るばかりだ。
examples.translation: We are ready to move into the new house.

examples.romaji: Ato wa kagu o ireru bakari desu.
examples.kanji: 後[あと]は 家[か]具[ぐ]を入[い]れるばかりです。
examples.translation: The only thing for us to do is to put in the furniture.

examples.romaji: Mō shuppatsu suru bakari desu.
examples.kanji: もう出[しゅっ]発[ぱつ]するばかりです。
examples.translation: I am ready to leave now.

description.romaji: Expresses two actions or events in one sentence.
description.kanji: Expresses two actions or events in one sentence.

examples.romaji: Kanojo wa shi kaku bakari de naku piano mo hiku.
examples.kanji: 彼[かの]女[じょ]は 詩[し]を書[か]くばかりでなくピアノも 挽[ひ]く。
examples.translation: She not only writes poetry but also plays the piano.

examples.romaji: Aoki-sensei wa Eigo o oshieru bakari de naku honyaku mo shimasu.
examples.kanji: 青[あお]木[き]先[せん]生[せい]は 英[えい]語[ご]を教[おし]えるばかりでなく 翻[ほん]訳[やく]もします。
examples.translation: Prof. Aoki not only teaches English but also does translation.

examples.romaji: Ano kaisha wa seihin o yushutsu suru bakari de naku yunyū mo suru.
examples.kanji: あの 会[かい]社[しゃ]は 製[せい]品[ひん]を輸[ゆ]出[しゅつ]するばかりでなく 輸[ゆ]入[にゅう]もする。
examples.translation: That company not only exports but also imports goods.

description.romaji: Expresses two or more actions or events in one sentence.
description.kanji: Expresses two or more actions or events in one sentence.

examples.romaji: Oda-san wa e mo kaku shi, shashin mo torimasu.
examples.kanji: 小[お]田[だ]さんは 絵[え]も描[か]くし、 写[しゃ]真[しん]もとります。
examples.translation: Miss Oda not only does paintings but also takes photographs.

examples.romaji: Ano hito wa yoku taberu shi, yoku nomu shi, yoku shaberu.
examples.kanji: あの 人[ひと]はよく食[た]べるし、よく飲[の]むし、よくしゃべる。
examples.translation: He eats a lot, drinks a lot, and chatters a lot.

examples.romaji: Genryō wa fusoku suru shi, seisan wa genshō shimasu.
examples.kanji: 原[げん]料[りょう]は不[ふ]足[そく]するし、 生[せい]産[さん]は 減[げん]少[しょう]します。
examples.translation: Raw material becomes insufficient, and production decreases.

description.romaji: Expresses actions or states which regularly don't take place/exist or won't take place/exist. The auxiliary nai is attached to the verb for negation. This form is used for the plain style. The copula desu may be added to make the expression polite.
description.kanji: Expresses actions or states which regularly don't take place/exist or won't take place/exist. The auxiliary ない is attached to the verb for negation. This form is used for the plain style. The copula です may be added to make the expression polite.

examples.romaji: Kono tori wa tobanai (desu).
examples.kanji: この 鳥[とり]は飛[と]ばない（です）。
examples.translation: This bird does not fly.

examples.romaji: Aoki-san wa niku o tabenai (desu).
examples.kanji: 青[あお]木[き]さんは 肉[にく]を食[た]べない（です）。
examples.translation: Mr. Aoki doesn't eat meat.

examples.romaji: Yamanaka-san wa tenisu tōnamento ni sanka shinai (desu).
examples.kanji: 山[やま]中[なか]さんはテニストーナメントに参[さん]加[か]しない（です）。
examples.translation: Miss Yamanaka won't participate in the tennis tournament.

description.romaji: Expresses a person's intention not to do something.
description.kanji: Expresses a person's intention not to do something.

examples.romaji: Ima wa ie o kawanai tsumori da.
examples.kanji: 今[いま]は 家[いえ]を買[か]わないつもりだ。
examples.translation: I don't intend to buy a house now.

examples.romaji: Kono kisoku wa kaenai tsumori desu.
examples.kanji: この 規[き]則[そく]は変[か]えないつもりです。
examples.translation: We don't need to change this regulation.

examples.romaji: Watashi wa kare no iken ni dōi shinai tsumori deshita.
examples.kanji: 私[わたし]は 彼[かれ]の 意[い]見[けん]に同[どう]意[い]しないつもりでした。
examples.translation: I didn't intend to agree with his opinion.

conjugation.translation:
• "I don't expect that ~"
  • "It is not expected that ~"

description.romaji: Expresses the speaker's expectation that something won't take place.
description.kanji: Expresses the speaker's expectation that something won't take place.

examples.romaji: Kida-san wa kayōbi made ni Amerika kara kaeranai hazu da.
examples.kanji: 木[き]田[だ]さんは 火[か]曜[よう]日[び]までにアメリカから帰[かえ]らないはずだ。
examples.translation: It is not expected that Mr. Kida will return from America by Tuesday.

examples.romaji: Asoko ni wa apāto o tatenai hazu desu.
examples.kanji: あそこにはアパートを建[た]てないはずです。
examples.translation: I don't expect that they will build an apartment house over there.

examples.romaji: Kyō wa gaishutsu shinai hazu datta.
examples.kanji: 今日[きょう]は外[がい]出[しゅつ]しないはずだった。
examples.translation: I was not expected to go out today.

description.romaji: Expresses the speaker's negative conjecture.
description.kanji: Expresses the speaker's negative conjecture.

examples.romaji: Tōbun ame wa yamanai darō.
examples.kanji: 当[とう]分[ぶん]雨[あめ]は止[や]まないだろう。
examples.translation: The rain probably won't stop for a while.

examples.romaji: Waga chīmu wa ashita no shiai ni yaburenai darō.
examples.kanji: わがチームは 明日[あした]の 試[し]合[あい]に敗[やぶ]れないだろう。
examples.translation: Our team probably won't lose tomorrow's game.

examples.romaji: Ano mise wa suiyōbi wa eigyō shinai deshō.
examples.kanji: あの 店[みせ]は 水[すい]曜[よう]日[び]は営[えい]業[ぎょう]しないでしょう。
examples.translation: That store probably doesn't do business on Wednesdays.

description.romaji: Expresses the speaker's negative speculation or guess.
description.kanji: Expresses the speaker's negative speculation or guess.

examples.romaji: Ano hito wa Nihongo ga wakaranai kamoshirenai.
examples.kanji: あの 人[ひと]は 日[に]本[ほん]語[ご]が分[わ]からないかもしれない。
examples.translation: He might not understand Japanese.

examples.romaji: Kyō wa Fuji-san ga mienai kamoshiremasen.
examples.kanji: 今日[きょう]は 富[ふ]士[じ]山[さん]が見[み]えないかもしれません。
examples.translation: Mt. Fuji might not be visible today.

examples.romaji: Kore wa kisoku ni ihan shinai kamoshiremasen.
examples.kanji: これは 規[き]則[そく]に違[い]反[はん]しないかもしれません。
examples.translation: This might not violate the regulation.

conjugation.translation:
• "must not be"
  • "There is no doubt that ~ not ~"

description.romaji: Expresses the speaker's negative guess with confidence.
description.kanji: Expresses the speaker's negative guess with confidence.

examples.romaji: Ogawa-san wa sake o nomanai ni chigainai.
examples.kanji: 小[お]川[がわ]さんは 酒[さけ]を飲[の]まないにちがいない。
examples.translation: There is no doubt that Mr. Ogawa does not drink.

examples.romaji: Buraun-san wa mō Nihon ni inai ni chigai arimasen.
examples.kanji: ブラウンさんはもう 日[に]本[ほん]にいないにちがいありません。
examples.translation: Mr. Brown must not be in Japan anymore.

examples.romaji: Kimura-san wa yoru wa unten shinai ni chigai arimasen.
examples.kanji: 木[き]村[むら]さんは 夜[よる]は運[うん]転[てん]しないにちがいありません。
examples.translation: There is no doubt that Miss Kimura does not drive at night.

description.romaji: Both no and koto are nominalizers which make a negative verb into a negative gerund, or a negative clause into a negative noun phrase.
description.kanji: Both の and こと are nominalizers which make a negative verb into a negative gerund, or a negative clause into a negative noun phrase.

examples.romaji: Yakusoku o yaburanai koto wa taisetsu desu.
examples.kanji: 約[やく]束[そく]を破[やぶ]らないことは 大[たい]切[せつ]です。
examples.translation: Not breaking promises is important.

examples.romaji: Yasai o tabenai no wa karada ni warui.
examples.kanji: 野[や]菜[さい]を食[た]べないのは 体[からだ]に 悪[わる]い。
examples.translation: It is bad for the health not to eat vegetables.

examples.romaji: Hara-san ga Orinpikku ni kuni o daihyō shinai no/koto o shirimasen deshita.
examples.kanji: 原[はら]さんがオリンピックに 国[くに]を代[だい]表[ひょう]しないの・ことを 知[し]りませんでした。
examples.translation: I didn't know that Mr. Hara would not represent the country in the Olympics.

description.romaji: Expresses non-performance of an action. The auxiliaries nai and zu are used for negation. The zu ni form for suru-verbs is sezu ni (not shizu ni).
description.kanji: Expresses non-performance of an action. The auxiliaries ない and ず are used for negation. The ずに form for する-verbs is せずに (not しずに).

examples.romaji: Samu wa gakkō e ikanai de/ikazu ni uchi ni imashita.
examples.kanji: サムは 学[がっ]校[こう]へ行[い]かないで・行[い]かずにうちにいました。
examples.translation: Sam did not go to school and stayed home.

examples.romaji: Gakusei wa tokidoki kyōshitsu no mado o shimenaide/shimezu ni kaerimasu.
examples.kanji: 学[がく]生[せい]は 時[とき]々[どき]教[きょう]室[しつ]の 窓[まど]を閉[し]めないで・閉[し]めずに 帰[かえ]ります。
examples.translation: Sometimes students go home without closing the windows of the classroom.

examples.romaji: Yūbe wa benkyō shinai de/benkyō sezu ni nemashita.
examples.kanji: ゆうべは勉[べん]強[きょう]しないで・勉[べん]強[きょう]せずに 寝[ね]ました。
examples.translation: Last night I didn't study and went to bed.

description.romaji: Expresses a negative request.
description.kanji: Expresses a negative request.

examples.romaji: Rōka no dentō o kesanai de kudasai.
examples.kanji: 廊[ろう]下[か]の 電[でん]灯[とう]を消[け]さないでください。
examples.translation: Please don't turn off the lights in the corridor.

examples.romaji: Sono doa o akenai de kudasai.
examples.kanji: そのドアを開[あ]けないでください。
examples.translation: Please don't open that door.

examples.romaji: Gogo rokuji igo wa shinamono o haitatsu shinai de kudasai.
examples.kanji: 午[ご]後[ご]六[ろく]時[じ]以[い]後[ご]は 品[しな]物[もの]を配[はい]達[たつ]しないでください。
examples.translation: Please don't deliver goods after 6 P.M.

description.romaji: Indicates that actions or events sometimes do not occur.
description.kanji: Indicates that actions or events sometimes do not occur.

examples.romaji: Kono beru wa naranai koto ga aru.
examples.kanji: このベルは鳴[な]らないことがある。
examples.translation: There are times when this bell does not ring.

examples.romaji: Sofu wa asa hayaku okinai koto ga aru.
examples.kanji: 祖[そ]父[ふ]は 朝[あさ]早[はや]く起[お]きないことがある。
examples.translation: There are times when my grandfather doesn't get up early in the morning.

examples.romaji: Koko ni wa chūsha o kyoka shinai koto ga arimasu.
examples.kanji: ここには 駐[ちゅう]車[しゃ]を許[きょ]可[か]しないことがあります。
examples.translation: There are times when they don't permit parking cars here.

description.romaji: Expresses the speaker's decision not to do something.
description.kanji: Expresses the speaker's decision not to do something.

examples.romaji: Ashita kara tabako o suwanai koto ni suru.
examples.kanji: 明日[あした]からたばこを吸[す]わないことにする。
examples.translation: I decided not to smoke starting tomorrow.

examples.romaji: Koko ni hana o uenai koto ni shimashita.
examples.kanji: ここに 花[はな]を植[う]えないことにしました。
examples.translation: I decided not to plant flowers here.

examples.romaji: Shibaraku soto de shokuji shinai koto ni shimasu.
examples.kanji: しばらく 外[そと]で食[しょく]事[じ]しないことにします。
examples.translation: I've decided not to dine out for a while.

description.romaji: Expresses a negative decision made by others, rather than the speaker.
description.kanji: Expresses a negative decision made by others, rather than the speaker.

examples.romaji: Watashi-tachi wa sono ryokan de tomaranai koto ni naru darō.
examples.kanji: 私[わたし]達[たち]はその 旅[りょ]館[かん]で泊[と]まらないことになるだろう。
examples.translation: It will probably be decided that we won't stay overnight at that Japanese inn.

examples.romaji: Kida-san wa kaisha o yamenai koto ni narimashita.
examples.kanji: 木[き]田[だ]さんは 会[かい]社[しゃ]を辞[や]めないことになりました。
examples.translation: It has been decided that Miss Kida won't quit the company.

examples.romaji: Akutenkō no tame fune wa shukkō shinai koto ni narimashita.
examples.kanji: 悪[あく]天[てん]候[こう]のため 船[ふね]は出[しゅっ]航[こう]しないことになりました。
examples.translation: It has been decided that the ship won't sail due to the bad weather.

description.romaji: Expresses a temporal limit for a negative action or event. The tense of the sentence is determined by the verb in the main clause.
description.kanji: Expresses a temporal limit for a negative action or event. The tense of the sentence is determined by the verb in the main clause.

examples.romaji: Ame ga furanai uchi ni kaerimashō.
examples.kanji: 雨[あめ]が降[ふ]らないうちに 帰[かえ]りましょう。
examples.translation: Let's go home before it rains.

examples.romaji: Kodomo ga okinai uchi ni asagohan o tabemashita.
examples.kanji: 子[こ]供[ども]が起[お]きないうちに 朝[あさ]ご 飯[はん]を 食[た]べました。
examples.translation: I ate breakfast before my child got up.

examples.romaji: Zairyō ga fusoku shinai uchi ni chūmon shimashita.
examples.kanji: 材[ざい]料[りょう]が不[ふ]足[そく]しないうちに 注[ちゅう]文[もん]しました。
examples.translation: We ordered before we were short of the materials.

conjugation.translation:
• "be better not to do ~"
  • "had better not do ~"

description.romaji: Expresses advice not to do something. Hō is a pseudo noun. Desu may be added to the adjective ii to make the speech polite.
description.kanji: Expresses advice not to do something. ほう is a pseudo noun. です may be added to the adjective いい to make the speech polite.

examples.romaji: Kono koto wa dare ni mo hanasanai hō ga ii (desu).
examples.kanji: この 事[こと]はだれにも話[はな]さないほうがいい（です）。
examples.translation: As for this matter, it is better not to tell anyone.

examples.romaji: Pātī de nomisuginai hō ga ii (desu) yo.
examples.kanji: パーティーで飲[の]みすぎないほうがいい（です）よ。
examples.translation: You had better not drink too much at the party.

examples.romaji: Ano kaisha to keiyaku shinai hō ga ii (desu).
examples.kanji: あの 会[かい]社[しゃ]と契[けい]約[やく]しないほうがいい（です）。
examples.translation: It is better not to contract with that company.

conjugation.translation:
• "instead of not doing ~"
  • "make up for not doing ~"

description.romaji: Expresses the thought that a certain action will not be carried out, and that instead another action will take place. Note, as in the first example below, that a verb modifier (in this case, the destination) is often of crucial importance.
description.kanji: Expresses the thought that a certain action will not be carried out, and that instead another action will take place. Note, as in the first example below, that a verb modifier (in this case, the destination) is often of crucial importance.

examples.romaji: Kanada e ikanai kawari ni Hawai e iku.
examples.kanji: カナダへ行[い]かない 代[か]わりにハワイへ 行[い]く。
examples.translation: Instead of (not) going to Canada, I'll go to Hawaii.

examples.romaji: Abe-san wa niku o tabenai kawari ni yasai o takusan tabemasu.
examples.kanji: 阿[あ]部[べ]さんは 肉[にく]を食[た]べない 代[か]わりに 野[や]菜[さい]をたくさん 食[た]べます。
examples.translation: Miss Abe eats a lot of vegetables to make up for not eating meat.

examples.romaji: Kyō shigoto shinai kawari ni doyōbi ni shigoto suru.
examples.kanji: 今日[きょう]仕[し]事[ごと]しない 代[か]わりに 土[ど]曜[よう]日[び]に 仕[し]事[ごと]する。
examples.translation: I'll work on Saturday to make up for not working today.

conjugation.translation:
• "although ~ not"
  • "in spite of the fact that ~ not"

description.romaji: Expresses a negative action which is followed by a result contrary to expectation.
description.kanji: Expresses a negative action which is followed by a result contrary to expectation.

examples.romaji: Mada goji ni naranai noni, mō hi ga kuremashita.
examples.kanji: まだ五[ご]時[じ]にならないのに、もう 日[ひ]が 暮[く]れました。
examples.translation: It's dark already, although it isn't five o'clock yet.

examples.romaji: Sensei ga tarinai noni yatoimasen.
examples.kanji: 先[せん]生[せい]が足[た]りないのに 雇[やと]いません。
examples.translation: Although we don't have enough teachers, they won't hire any more.

examples.romaji: Chūmon shinai noni hon ga todokimashita.
examples.kanji: 注[ちゅう]文[もん]しないのに 本[ほん]が 届[とど]きました。
examples.translation: A book arrived in spite of the fact that I did not order it.

description.romaji: Expresses a negative condition that brings about an inevitable result.
description.kanji: Expresses a negative condition that brings about an inevitable result.

examples.romaji: Kusuri o nomanai to netsu ga sagaranai.
examples.kanji: 薬[くすり]を飲[の]まないと 熱[ねつ]が 下[さ]がらない。
examples.translation: If you don't take medicine, your fever won't go down.

examples.romaji: Dentō o tsukenai to mienai.
examples.kanji: 電[でん]灯[とう]をつけないと 見[み]えない。
examples.translation: If I don't turn on the light, I can't see.

examples.romaji: Minna ga kyōryoku shinai to kono shigoto wa kansei shimasen.
examples.kanji: みんなが協[きょう]力[りょく]しないとこの 仕[し]事[ごと]は 完[かん]成[せい]しません。
examples.translation: If everyone doesn't cooperate, this job won't be completed.

conjugation.translation:
• "if ~ not"
  • "if it is not the case ~"

description.romaji: Expresses a negative supposition or condition.
description.kanji: Expresses a negative supposition or condition.

examples.romaji: Noda-san ga ikanai (no) nara, watashi mo ikanai.
examples.kanji: 野[の]田[だ]さんが行[い]かない（の）なら、 私[わたし]も 行[い]かない。
examples.translation: If Mr. Noda doesn't go, I won't go either.

examples.romaji: Terebi o minai (no) nara, keshi nasai.
examples.kanji: テレビを見[み]ない（の）なら、 消[け]しなさい。
examples.translation: If you're not watching the TV, turn it off.

examples.romaji: Ima happyō shinai (no) nara, itsu suru tsumori desu ka.
examples.kanji: 今[いま]発[はっ]表[ぴょう]しない（の）なら、いつするつもりですか。
examples.translation: If you don't announce it now, when do you intend to do it?

description.romaji: Expresses by means of a negative verb a reason or motive for doing something.
description.kanji: Expresses by means of a negative verb a reason or motive for doing something.

examples.romaji: Kaze o hikanai yō ni sētā o kiru.
examples.kanji: かぜを引[ひ]かないようにセーターを 着[き]る。
examples.translation: I wear a sweater in order not to catch cold.

examples.romaji: Nomisuginai yō ni ki o tsukemasu.
examples.kanji: 飲[の]みすぎないように 気[き]をつけます。
examples.translation: I'll be careful not to drink too much.

examples.romaji: Rakudai shinai yō ni shikkari benkyō shinasai.
examples.kanji: 落[らく]第[だい]しないようにしっかり 勉[べん]強[きょう]しなさい。
examples.translation: Study hard so that you won't fail the examination.

conjugation.kanji: Vneg + ないように 言[い]う

description.romaji: Expresses an indirect command. The verb iu may be replaced by other verbs such as tanomu (ask) or chūkoku suru (advise) to express requests or suggestions.
description.kanji: Expresses an indirect command. The verb 言[い]う may be replaced by other verbs such as 頼[たの]む (ask) or 忠告[ちゅうこく]する (advise) to express requests or suggestions.

examples.romaji: Kodomo ni rōka o hashiranai yō ni iu.
examples.kanji: 子[こ]供[ども]に 廊[ろう]下[か]を走[はし]らないように 言[い]う。
examples.translation: I'll tell the children not to run in the corridor.

examples.romaji: Watashi wa Ono-san ni mado o akenai yō ni tanomimashita.
examples.kanji: 私[わたし]は 小[お]野[の]さんに 窓[まど]を開[あ]けないように 頼[たの]みました。
examples.translation: I asked Miss Ono not to open the window.

examples.romaji: Kare wa watashi ni ima kabu ni tōshi shinai yō ni chūkoku shimashita.
examples.kanji: 彼[かれ]は 私[わたし]に 今[いま]株[かぶ]に投[とう]資[し]しないように 忠[ちゅう]告[こく]しました。
examples.translation: He advised me not to invest in stocks now.

description.romaji: Expresses with a negative verb some change that takes place gradually.
description.kanji: Expresses with a negative verb some change that takes place gradually.

examples.romaji: Hayashi-san wa tabako o suwanai yō ni narimashita.
examples.kanji: 林[はやし]さんはたばこを吸[す]わないようになりました。
examples.translation: Mr. Hayashi has reached the point where he does not smoke.

examples.romaji: Jimu wa gakkō ni okurenai yō ni narimashita.
examples.kanji: ジムは 学[がっ]校[こう]に遅[おく]れないようになりました。
examples.translation: Jim has reached the point where he is not late for school. (Jim is not late for school anymore.)

examples.romaji: Noda-san wa zangyō shinai yō ni narimashita.
examples.kanji: 野[の]田[だ]さんは残[ざん]業[ぎょう]しないようになりました。
examples.translation: Miss Noda has reached the point where she doesn't work overtime. (Miss Noda doesn't work overtime anymore.)

description.romaji: Expresses with a negative verb a person's efforts to cause a change in behavior.
description.kanji: Expresses with a negative verb a person's efforts to cause a change in behavior.

examples.romaji: Yasai o nokosanai yō ni shinasai.
examples.kanji: 野[や]菜[さい]を残[のこ]さないようにしなさい。
examples.translation: Make sure that you don't leave vegetables (uneaten).

examples.romaji: Amari yoru osoku shawā o abinai yō ni suru.
examples.kanji: あまり 夜[よる]おそくシャワーを浴[あ]びないようにする。
examples.translation: I try not to take a shower late at night.

examples.romaji: Otōto to kenka shinai yō ni shimasu.
examples.kanji: 弟[おとうと]とけんかしないようにします。
examples.translation: I'll try not to quarrel with my younger brother.

description.romaji:
Expresses the passive form. Reru is attached to Regular I verbs and rareru to Regular II verbs. The irregular verbs kuru and suru become korareru and sareru. All passive verbs are Regular II verbs.

There are two types of passives in Japanese: direct and indirect. The direct passive is similar to the English passive in which the object of the active sentence becomes the subject of the passive sentence (Exampe 1). The agent (performer of the action) takes the particle ni. The agent may be omitted when it is not important or unknown (Example 2). In the indirect passive, the person who becomes the subject of the passive sentence is the one who is adversely affected by someone else's action or an unpleasant event (Example 3). For this passive, both transitive and intransitive verbs may be used (Examples 3, 4 and 5).
description.kanji:
Expresses the passive form. れる is attached to Regular I verbs and られる to Regular II verbs. The irregular verbs 来[く]る and する become 来[こ]られる and される. All passive verbs are Regular II verbs.

There are two types of passives in Japanese: direct and indirect. The direct passive is similar to the English passive in which the object of the active sentence becomes the subject of the passive sentence (Exampe 1). The agent (performer of the action) takes the particle に. The agent may be omitted when it is not important or unknown (Example 2). In the indirect passive, the person who becomes the subject of the passive sentence is the one who is adversely affected by someone else's action or an unpleasant event (Example 3). For this passive, both transitive and intransitive verbs may be used (Examples 3, 4 and 5).

examples.romaji: Tokidoki Tomu wa Jimu ni damasareru.
examples.kanji: 時[とき]々[どき]トムはジムにだまされる。
examples.translation: Sometimes Tom is deceived by Jim.

examples.romaji: Asoko ni biru ga tateraremasu.
examples.kanji: あそこにビルが建[た]てられます。
examples.translation: A building will be built over there.

examples.romaji: Watashi wa otōto ni pai o taberaremashita.
examples.kanji: 私[わたし]は 弟[おとうと]にパイを食[た]べられました。
examples.translation: I had my pie eaten by my younger brother.

examples.romaji: Gorufujō de ame ni furaremashita.
examples.kanji: ゴルフ 場[じょう]で 雨[あめ]に降[ふ]られました。
examples.translation: We were rained on at the golf course.

examples.romaji: Watashi wa Akiko-san ni totsuzen uchi e koraremashita.
examples.kanji: 私[わたし]は 秋[あき]子[こ]さんに 突[とつ]然[ぜん]うちへ来[こ]られました。
examples.translation: Akiko came to my home unexpectedly (and I was unhappy).

description.romaji: Expresses potential. Reru is attached to Regular I verbs and rareru to Regular II verbs. The potential forms for the irregular verbs kuru and suru are korareru and dekiru (not sareru).
description.kanji: Expresses potential. れる is attached to Regular I verbs and られる to Regular II verbs. The potential forms for the irregular verbs 来[く]る and する are 来[こ]られる and 出[で]来[き]る (not される).

examples.romaji: Anata wa kyō tenrankai ni ikaremasu ka.
examples.kanji: あなたは 今日[きょう]展[てん]覧[らん]会[かい]に行[い]かれますか。
examples.translation: Can you go to the exhibition today?

examples.romaji: Asa goji ni wa okirarenai.
examples.kanji: 朝[あさ]五[ご]時[じ]には起[お]きられない。
examples.translation: I can't get up at five o'clock in the morning.

examples.romaji: Mina-san ashita hachiji made koraremasu ka.
examples.kanji: 皆[みな]さん 明日[あした]八[はち]時[じ]までに来[こ]られますか。
examples.translation: Can everyone come by eight o'clock tomorrow?

examples.romaji: Kono terebi wa shūri dekinai.
examples.kanji: このテレビは修[しゅう]理[り]出[で]来[き]ない。
examples.translation: I can't repair this TV set.

description.romaji: Used for the honorific style of speech. Reru is attached to Regular I verbs and rareru to Regular II verbs. The irregular verbs kuru and suru become korareru and sareru.
description.kanji: Used for the honorific style of speech. れる is attached to Regular I verbs and られる to Regular II verbs. The irregular verbs 来[く]る and する become 来[こ]られる and される.

examples.romaji: Nakamura-sensei ga Nihon no keizai ni tsuite hanasaremasu.
examples.kanji: 中[なか]村[むら]先[せん]生[せい]が 日[に]本[ほん]の 経[けい]済[ざい]について話[はな]されます。
examples.translation: Prof. Nakamura will speak about the Japanese economy.

examples.romaji: Kin'yōbi ni wa Hara-sensei wa oshierarenai.
examples.kanji: 金[きん]曜[よう]日[び]には 原[はら]先[せん]生[せい]は教[おし]えられない。
examples.translation: Prof. Hara does not teach on Fridays.

examples.romaji: Sono kaigi de Oka-buchō ga nando mo shitsumon saremashita.
examples.kanji: その 会[かい]議[ぎ]で 岡[おか]部[ぶ]長[ちょう]が 何[なん]度[ど]も質[しつ]問[もん]されました。
examples.translation: Mr. Oka, the department head, asked questions many times at that meeting.

description.romaji: Expresses the causative form. Seru is attached to Regular I verbs and saseru to Regular II verbs. The irregular verbs kuru and suru become kosaseru and saseru. These causative verbs are Regular II verbs. The shortened causative form may be obtained by changing the final seru to su, e.g. arukaseru → arukasu; tabesaseru → tabesasu; kosaseru → kosasu; saseru → sasu. The causative verbs of this shortened form are Regular I verbs conjugated on the Sa row. The person who causes someone to do something usually takes the particle wa or ga and the person who is made or allowed to do something is marked by o or ni. When the verb is transitive and the direct object marker o appears, the person caused to do something must be marked by ni (Example 1). When the verb is intransitive, that person takes ni if he performs an action willingly (Example 2). O is used regardless of the person's volition (Example 3).
description.kanji: Expresses the causative form. せる is attached to Regular I verbs and させる to Regular II verbs. The irregular verbs 来[く]る and する become 来[こ]させる and させる. These causative verbs are Regular II verbs. The shortened causative form may be obtained by changing the final せる to す, e.g. 歩[ある]かせる → 歩[ある]かす; 食[た]べさせる → 食[た]べさす; 来[こ]させる → 来[こ]さす; させる → さす. The causative verbs of this shortened form are Regular I verbs conjugated on the サ row. The person who causes someone to do something usually takes the particle は or が and the person who is made or allowed to do something is marked by を or に. When the verb is transitive and the direct object marker を appears, the person caused to do something must be marked by に (Example 1). When the verb is intransitive, that person takes に if he performs an action willingly (Example 2). を is used regardless of the person's volition (Example 3).

examples.romaji: Haha wa imōto ni barē o narawaseru/narawasu.
examples.kanji: 母[はは]は 妹[いもうと]にバレーを習[なら]わせる・習[なら]わす。
examples.translation: My mother makes/lets my younger sister learn ballet.

examples.romaji: Watashi wa kodomo-tachi ni tento de nesasemashita/nesashimashita.
examples.kanji: 私[わたし]は 子[こ]供[ども]達[たち]にテントで寝[ね]させました・寝[ね]さしました。
examples.translation: I let my children sleep in a tent.

examples.romaji: Oda-san wa musuko o Amerika ni ryūgaku sasemashita/ryūgaku sashimashita.
examples.kanji: 小[お]田[だ]さんは 息[むす]子[こ]をアメリカに留[りゅう]学[がく]させました・留[りゅう]学[がく]さしました。
examples.translation: Mr. Oda made/let his son study in America.

conjugation.kanji: Vneg + せられる・させられる

description.romaji: Expresses the causative-passive form. Serareru is attached to Regular I verbs and saserareru to Regular II verbs. The irregular verbs kuru and suru become kosaserareru and saserareru. The shortened causative-passive form is made by attaching reru to the negative base of the shortened causative verbs made from Regular I verbs; e.g. matasu → matasa + reru → matasareru (Example 1). All causative-passive verbs are Regular II verbs.
description.kanji: Expresses the causative-passive form. せられる is attached to Regular I verbs and させられる to Regular II verbs. The irregular verbs 来[く]る and する become 来[こ]させられる and させられる. The shortened causative-passive form is made by attaching れる to the negative base of the shortened causative verbs made from Regular I verbs; e.g. 待[ま]たす → 待[ま]たさ + れる → 待[ま]たされる (Example 1). All causative-passive verbs are Regular II verbs.

examples.romaji: Itsumo ginkō de mataserareru (matasareru).
examples.kanji: いつも 銀[ぎん]行[こう]で待[ま]たせられる（待[ま]たされる）。
examples.translation: I am always made to wait at the bank.

examples.romaji: Kachō ni shorui o shirabesaseraremashita.
examples.kanji: 課[か]長[ちょう]に 書[しょ]類[るい]を調[しら]べさせられました。
examples.translation: I was made to check the documents by the section chief.

examples.romaji: Kaigi ni shusseki saseraremashita.
examples.kanji: 会[かい]議[ぎ]に出[しゅっ]席[せき]させられました。
examples.translation: I was made to attend the meeting.

description.romaji: Past tense of Vneg nai. The copula desu may be added to make the speech polite.
description.kanji: Past tense of Vneg ない. The copula です may be added to make the speech polite.

examples.romaji: Kyonen wa Fuji-san ni noboranakatta (desu).
examples.kanji: 去[きょ]年[ねん]は 富[ふ]士[じ]山[さん]に登[のぼ]らなかった（です）。
examples.translation: I did not climb Mt. Fuji last year.

examples.romaji: Watashi wa Masako-san ni shashin o misenakatta (desu).
examples.kanji: 私[わたし]は 正[まさ]子[こ]さんに 写[しゃ]真[しん]を見[み]せなかった（です）。
examples.translation: I did not show the photos to Masako.

examples.romaji: Waga chīmu wa yūshō shinakatta (desu).
examples.kanji: わがチームは優[ゆう]勝[しょう]しなかった（です）。
examples.translation: Our team did not win the championship.

conjugation.kanji: Vneg + なければ・なかったら

description.romaji: Expresses a negative condition.
description.kanji: Expresses a negative condition.

examples.romaji: Isoganakereba/nakattara, ma ni awanai yo.
examples.kanji: 急[いそ]がなければ・なかったら、 間[ま]に 合[あ]わないよ。
examples.translation: If you don't hurry, you won't be in time.

examples.romaji: Kiri ga harenakereba/nakattara, hikōki wa tobimasen.
examples.kanji: きりが晴[は]れなければ・なかったら、 飛[ひ]行[こう]機[き]は 飛[と]びません。
examples.translation: If the fog doesn't clear up, the airplane won't fly.

examples.romaji: Shachō ga kyoka shinakereba/nakattara, kono purojekuto wa dekimasen.
examples.kanji: 社[しゃ]長[ちょう]が許[きょ]可[か]しなければ・なかったら、このプロジェクトは 出[で]来[き]ません。
examples.translation: If the company president doesn't give permission, we cannot do this project.

description.romaji: Expresses the idea of obligation or duty. Nakereba narimasen is the polite style of speech.
description.kanji: Expresses the idea of obligation or duty. なければなりません is the polite style of speech.

examples.romaji: Nihongo de sakubun o kakanakereba naranai.
examples.kanji: 日[に]本[ほん]語[ご]で 作[さく]文[ぶん]を書[か]かなければならない。
examples.translation: I have to write a composition in Japanese.

examples.romaji: Kono shinamono wa kayōbi made ni todokenakereba narimasen.
examples.kanji: この 品[しな]物[もの]は 火[か]曜[よう]日[び]までに届[とど]けなければなりません。
examples.translation: We must deliver this article by Tuesday.

examples.romaji: Shiai ga aru kara, mainichi renshū shinakereba naranai.
examples.kanji: 試[し]合[あい]があるから、 毎[まい]日[にち]練[れん]習[しゅう]しなければならない。
examples.translation: Because we'll have a tournament, we have to practice every day.

conjugation.translation:
• "do not do ~ and ~"
  • "because ~ do not do ~"

description.romaji: Negative te form of the verb and indicates a cause or reason for an action or event.
description.kanji: Negative て form of the verb and indicates a cause or reason for an action or event.

examples.romaji: Hikōki ga teikoku ni tsukanakute enkai ni okuremashita.
examples.kanji: 飛[ひ]行[こう]機[き]が 定[てい]刻[こく]に着[つ]かなくて 宴[えん]会[かい]に 遅[おく]れました。
examples.translation: The airplane didn't arrive on schedule and I was late for the banquet.

examples.romaji: Kanji ga oboerarenakute komaru.
examples.kanji: 漢[かん]字[じ]が覚[おぼ]えられなくて 困[こま]る。
examples.translation: Because I can't memorize kanji, I'm in trouble.

examples.romaji: Shukudai o teishutsu shinakute sensei ni shikararemashita.
examples.kanji: 宿[しゅく]題[だい]を提[てい]出[しゅつ]しなくて 先[せん]生[せい]に 叱[しか]られました。
examples.translation: I did not hand in my homework and was scolded by my teacher.

description.romaji: Expresses a negative condition.
description.kanji: Expresses a negative condition.

examples.romaji: Ame ga yamanakute mo dekakeru tsumori da.
examples.kanji: 雨[あめ]が止[や]まなくても 出[で]かけるつもりだ。
examples.translation: Even if the rain doesn't stop, I intend to go out.

examples.romaji: Nedan o sagenakute mo kono shinamono wa mada yoku ureru.
examples.kanji: 値[ね]段[だん]を下[さ]げなくてもこの 品[しな]物[もの]はまだよく 売[う]れる。
examples.translation: Even though we haven't lowered the price, this article still sells well.

examples.romaji: Ryōshin ga sansei shinakute mo Furansu e ikitai (desu).
examples.kanji: 両[りょう]親[しん]が賛[さん]成[せい]しなくてもフランスへ 行[い]きたい（です）。
examples.translation: Even if my parents do not approve, I'd like to go to France.

conjugation.translation:
• "It is all right if ~ not"
  • "don't have to"

description.romaji: Expresses the idea of non-obligation or duty.
description.kanji: Expresses the idea of non-obligation or duty.

examples.romaji: Kono hagaki ni kitte o haranakute mo ii (desu).
examples.kanji: この 葉[は]書[がき]に 切[きっ]手[て]をはらなくてもいい（です）。
examples.translation: You don't have to stick a stamp on this postcard.

examples.romaji: Shūmatsu wa hayaku okinakute mo ii (desu).
examples.kanji: 週[しゅう]末[まつ]は 早[はや]く起[お]きなくてもいい（です）。
examples.translation: I don't have to get up early on weekends.

examples.romaji: Kono ken wa ima kettei shinakute mo ii (desu).
examples.kanji: この 件[けん]は 今[いま]決[けっ]定[てい]しなくてもいい（です）。
examples.translation: We don't have to decide this matter now.

description.romaji: Expresses a condition. The main clause may involve an inevitable event, or the speaker's volition or hope.
description.kanji: Expresses a condition. The main clause may involve an inevitable event, or the speaker's volition or hope.

examples.romaji: Kikai ga areba, Kimura-san o tazunetai (desu).
examples.kanji: 機[き]会[かい]があれば、 木[き]村[むら]さんを 訪[たず]ねたい（です）。
examples.translation: If I have an opportunity, I'd like to visit Miss Kimura.

examples.romaji: Hachiji ni kochira o dereba, niji made ni achira ni tsuku.
examples.kanji: 八[はち]時[じ]にこちらを出[で]れば、 二[に]時[じ]までにあちらに 着[つ]く。
examples.translation: If we leave here at eight o'clock, we will arrive there by two o'clock.

examples.romaji: Yamada-san ga kureba, issho ni tenisu o suru tsumori da.
examples.kanji: 山[やま]田[だ]さんが来[く]れば、 一[いっ]緒[しょ]にテニスをするつもりだ。
examples.translation: If Mr. Yamada comes, I intend to play tennis with him.

conjugation.translation:
• "you need only"
  • "all you have to do is"

description.romaji: Suggests the only action the listener should take in a certain situation.
description.kanji: Suggests the only action the listener should take in a certain situation.

examples.romaji: Wakaranakereba, sensei ni kikeba ii (desu).
examples.kanji: 分[わ]からなければ、 先[せん]生[せい]に聞[き]けばいい（です）。
examples.translation: If you don't understand, all you have to do is to ask your teacher.

examples.romaji: Ashita no tesuto ni wa kono ka no kanji o oboereba ii (desu).
examples.kanji: 明日[あした]のテストにはこの 課[か]の 漢[かん]字[じ]を覚[おぼ]えればいい（です）。
examples.translation: For tomorrow's test, you need only memorize the kanji in this lesson.

examples.romaji: Isogu (no) nara, denwa de chūmon sureba ii (desu).
examples.kanji: 急[いそ]ぐ（の）なら、 電[でん]話[わ]で注[ちゅう]文[もん]すればいい（です）。
examples.translation: If you want it in a hurry, all you have to do is to order by phone.

description.romaji: Expresses the speaker's regret for something he hasn't done. Desu may be added to the adjective yokatta (past form of ii/yoi) to make the speech polite.
description.kanji: Expresses the speaker's regret for something he hasn't done. です may be added to the adjective よかった (past form of いい・よい) to make the speech polite.

examples.romaji: Ano hon o kaeba yokatta (desu).
examples.kanji: あの 本[ほん]を買[か]えばよかった（です）。
examples.translation: I wish I had bought that book.

examples.romaji: Motto yoku kangaerebe yokatta (desu).
examples.kanji: もっとよく考[かんが]えればよかった（です）。
examples.translation: I wish I had given more thought to it.

examples.romaji: Kono koto wa sensei to sōdan sureba yokatta (desu).
examples.kanji: このことは 先[せん]生[せい]と相[そう]談[だん]すればよかった（です）。
examples.translation: I wish I had consulted with my teacher about this matter.

description.romaji: Expresses a proportional relationship between two actions or states.
description.kanji: Expresses a proportional relationship between two actions or states.

examples.romaji: Minami e ikeba iku hodo/dake atatakaku naru.
examples.kanji: 南[みなみ]へ行[い]けば 行[い]くほど・だけ 暖[あたた]かくなる。
examples.translation: The further south you go, the warmer it gets.

examples.romaji: Kono e wa mireba miru hodo/dake utsukushii.
examples.kanji: この 絵[え]は見[み]れば 見[み]るほど・だけ 美[うつく]しい。
examples.translation: The more I look at this picture, the more beautiful it is.

examples.romaji: Gogaku wa benkyō sureba suru hodo/dake omoshiroku narimasu.
examples.kanji: 語[ご]学[がく]は勉[べん]強[きょう]すればするほど・だけ 面[おも]白[しろ]くなります。
examples.translation: The more you study language, the more interesting it becomes.

description.romaji: Expresses emphasis of a reason or cause.
description.kanji: Expresses emphasis of a reason or cause.

examples.romaji: O-kane ga ireba koso yoru mo hataraku.
examples.kanji: お 金[かね]が要[い]ればこそ 夜[よる]も 働[はたら]く。
examples.translation: Only because I need money, I work at night as well.

examples.romaji: Eigo ga dekireba koso Yano-san wa Amerika no daigaku ni hairemasu.
examples.kanji: 英[えい]語[ご]が出[で]来[き]ればこそ 矢[や]野[の]さんはアメリカの 大[だい]学[がく]に 入[はい]れます。
examples.translation: Only because she understands English, Miss Yano can enter an American college.

examples.romaji: Piano wa mainichi renshū sureba koso jōzu ni narimasu.
examples.kanji: ピアノは 毎[まい]日[にち]練[れん]習[しゅう]すればこそ 上[じょう]手[ず]になります。
examples.translation: Only because you practice every day, will you become good at the piano.

description.romaji: Expresses a direct command and is used by men in very informal speech.
description.kanji: Expresses a direct command and is used by men in very informal speech.

examples.romaji: Bōshi o nuge.
examples.kanji: 帽[ぼう]子[し]を脱[ぬ]げ。
examples.translation: Take off your hat.

examples.romaji: Hayaku nigero/nigeyo.
examples.kanji: 早[はや]く逃[に]げろ・逃[に]げよ。
examples.translation: Run away quick!

examples.romaji: Asaban undō seyo/undō shiro.
examples.kanji: 朝[あさ]晩[ばん]運[うん]動[どう]せよ・運[うん]動[どう]しろ。
examples.translation: Exercise morning and evening.

description.romaji: Expresses an indirect command and is used by men. The passive form iwareru (be told) may be used by men and women.
description.kanji: Expresses an indirect command and is used by men. The passive form 言[い]われる (be told) may be used by men and women.

examples.romaji: Ten'in ni sugu mihon o okure to iu.
examples.kanji: 店[てん]員[いん]にすぐ 見[み]本[ほん]を送[おく]れと 言[い]う。
