examples.translation: I'll tell the clerk to send the sample right away.

examples.romaji: Itsumo sensei ni Nihongo de kotaero/kotaeyo to iwaremasu.
examples.kanji: いつも 先[せん]生[せい]に 日[に]本[ほん]語[ご]で答[こた]えろ・答[こた]えよと 言[い]われます。
examples.translation: I'm always told by my teacher to answer in Japanese.

examples.romaji: Buchō ni kaigi o enki seyo/enki shiro to iwaremashita.
examples.kanji: 部[ぶ]長[ちょう]に 会[かい]議[ぎ]を延[えん]期[き]せよ・延[えん]期[き]しろと 言[い]われました。
examples.translation: I was told by the department head to postpone the meeting.

description.romaji: Expresses first person volition, invitation or suggestion in the plain style of speech.
description.kanji: Expresses first person volition, invitation or suggestion in the plain style of speech.

examples.romaji: Gogo toshokan de hon o yomō.
examples.kanji: 午[ご]後[ご]図[と]書[しょ]館[かん]で 本[ほん]を読[よ]もう。
examples.translation: I'll read a book in the library this afternoon.

examples.romaji: Kono pai o yottsu ni wakeyō.
examples.kanji: このパイを 四[よっ]つに分[わ]けよう。
examples.translation: Let's divide this pie in four.

examples.romaji: Watashi ga o-kyaku-san o kaijō e annai shiyō.
examples.kanji: 私[わたし]がお 客[きゃく]さんを 会[かい]場[じょう]へ案[あん]内[ない]しよう。
examples.translation: I'll lead the visitors to the assembly hall.

description.romaji: Expresses first person invitation or suggestion by asking in the plain style of speech.
description.kanji: Expresses first person invitation or suggestion by asking in the plain style of speech.

examples.romaji: Honda-san o pikunikku ni sasoō ka.
examples.kanji: 本[ほん]田[だ]さんをピクニックに誘[さそ]おうか。
examples.translation: Shall we invite Miss Honda to the picnic?

examples.romaji: Asoko ni kuruma o tomeyō ka.
examples.kanji: あそこに 車[くるま]を止[と]めようか。
examples.translation: Shall I park the car over there?

examples.romaji: Watashi ga bazā no uriage o keisan shiyō ka.
examples.kanji: 私[わたし]がバザーの 売[う]り 上[あ]げを計[けい]算[さん]しようか。
examples.translation: Shall I calculate the proceeds of the bazaar?

description.romaji: Expresses the speaker's thoughts about doing something.
description.kanji: Expresses the speaker's thoughts about doing something.

examples.romaji: Rainen atarashii kuruma o kaō to omou.
examples.kanji: 来[らい]年[ねん]新[あたら]しい 車[くるま]を買[か]おうと 思[おも]う。
examples.translation: I think I'll buy a new car next year.

examples.romaji: Kono shigoto o yameyō to omou.
examples.kanji: この 仕[し]事[ごと]を辞[や]めようと 思[おも]う。
examples.translation: I think I'll quit this job.

examples.romaji: Tomodachi o Tanaka-sensei ni shōkai shiyō to omoimasu.
examples.kanji: 友[とも]達[だち]を 田[た]中[なか]先[せん]生[せい]に紹[しょう]介[かい]しようと 思[おも]います。
examples.translation: I think I'll introduce my friend to Prof. Tanaka.

description.romaji: Expresses a person's effort to do something (often unsuccessfully).
description.kanji: Expresses a person's effort to do something (often unsuccessfully).

examples.romaji: Wakai otoko ga jitensha o nusumō to shimashita.
examples.kanji: 若[わか]い 男[おとこ]が 自[じ]転[てん]車[しゃ]を盗[ぬす]もうとしました。
examples.translation: A young man tried to steal a bicycle.

examples.romaji: Ani ni kuruma o kariyō to shimashita ga dame deshita.
examples.kanji: 兄[あに]に 車[くるま]を借[か]りようとしましたが 駄[だ]目[め]でした。
examples.translation: I tried to borrow the car from my older brother but didn't succeed.

examples.romaji: Akira wa itsumo Masao to kyōsō shiyō to shimasu.
examples.kanji: 明[あきら]はいつも 正[まさ]男[お]と競[きょう]争[そう]しようとします。
examples.translation: Akira always tries to compete with Masao (without success).

description.romaji: Expresses in a conditional clause an action which is about to take place.
description.kanji: Expresses in a conditional clause an action which is about to take place.

examples.romaji: Densha ni norō to suru to, doa ga shimarimashita.
examples.kanji: 電[でん]車[しゃ]に乗[の]ろうとすると、ドアが 閉[し]まりました。
examples.translation: Just as I was about to get on a train, the doors were closed.

examples.romaji: Shokuji o hajimeyō to suru to, denwa ga narimashita.
examples.kanji: 食[しょく]事[じ]を始[はじ]めようとすると、 電[でん]話[わ]が 鳴[な]りました。
examples.translation: Just as I was about to start the meal, the telephone rang.

examples.romaji: Gaishutsu shiyō to suru to, itsumo dare ka kuru.
examples.kanji: 外[がい]出[しゅつ]しようとすると、いつもだれか 来[く]る。
examples.translation: Just as I'm about to go out, someone always comes.

description.romaji: Used as a conjunction to link two or more actions or events.
description.kanji: Used as a conjunction to link two or more actions or events.

examples.romaji: Kami de hikōki o tsukutte tobasu.
examples.kanji: 紙[かみ]で 飛[ひ]行[こう]機[き]を作[つく]って飛[と]ばす。
examples.translation: I make airplanes with paper and fly them.

examples.romaji: Meguro de densha o orite gakkō made arukimasu.
examples.kanji: 目[め]黒[ぐろ]で 電[でん]車[しゃ]を降[お]りて学[がっ]校[こう]まで 歩[ある]きます。
examples.translation: I get off the train at Meguro and walk to school.

examples.romaji: Ie o sōji shite kaimono ni ikimashita.
examples.kanji: 家[いえ]を掃[そう]除[じ]して買[か]い 物[もの]に 行[い]きました。
examples.translation: I cleaned the house and went shopping.

description.romaji: Expresses the reason for or the cause of the action or event in the main clause.
description.kanji: Expresses the reason for or the cause of the action or event in the main clause.

examples.romaji: Ame ga futte tsuri ni ikemasen deshita.
examples.kanji: 雨[あめ]が降[ふ]って釣[つ]りに 行[い]けませんでした。
examples.translation: It rained, so we couldn't go fishing.

examples.romaji: Kare wa hatarakisugite byōki ni narimashita.
examples.kanji: 彼[かれ]は働[はたら]きすぎて病[びょう]気[き]になりました。
examples.translation: He became ill, because he worked too hard.

examples.romaji: Tomodachi ga kite issho ni bīru o nomimashita.
examples.kanji: 友[とも]達[だち]が来[き]て一[いっ]緒[しょ]にビールを 飲[の]みました。
examples.translation: My friend came, so we drank beer together.

description.romaji: Expresses how an action is performed.
description.kanji: Expresses how an action is performed.

examples.romaji: Kesa isoide uchi o demashita.
examples.kanji: 今朝[けさ]急[いそ]いでうちを 出[で]ました。
examples.translation: I left home in a hurry this evening.

examples.romaji: Kare wa sofa ni nete hon o yomu.
examples.kanji: 彼[かれ]はソファに寝[ね]て本[ほん]を 読[よ]む。
examples.translation: Lying on the sofa, he reads books.

examples.romaji: Kankyaku wa kiritsu shite hakushu shimashita.
examples.kanji: 観[かん]客[きゃく]は起[き]立[りつ]して拍[はく]手[しゅ]しました。
examples.translation: The audience stood up and clapped their hands.

description.romaji: Expresses a request.
description.kanji: Expresses a request.

examples.romaji: Kono shigoto o tetsudatte kudasai.
examples.kanji: この 仕[し]事[ごと]を手[て]伝[つだ]ってください。
examples.translation: Please help me with this work.

examples.romaji: Gakusei ni tenrankai ni iku yō ni susumete kudasai.
examples.kanji: 学[がく]生[せい]に 展[てん]覧[らん]会[かい]に 行[い]くように勧[すす]めてください。
examples.translation: Please encourage the students to go to the exhibition.

examples.romaji: Ashita no gozenchū ni kanarazu renraku shite kudasai.
examples.kanji: 明日[あした]の 午[ご]前[ぜん]中[ちゅう]に 必[かなら]ず連[れん]絡[らく]してください。
examples.translation: Please contact me tomorrow morning without fail.

description.romaji: Expresses an action in progress.
description.kanji: Expresses an action in progress.

examples.romaji: Haruko-san wa uta o utatte iru.
examples.kanji: 春[はる]子[こ]さんは 歌[うた]を歌[うた]っている。
examples.translation: Haruko is singing a song.

examples.romaji: Sensei ga gakusei ni kanji o kakasete imasu.
examples.kanji: 先[せん]生[せい]が 学[がく]生[せい]に 漢[かん]字[じ]を書[か]かせています。
examples.translation: A teacher is making students write kanji.

examples.romaji: Sumisu-sensei wa Nihon bungaku o kenkyū shite imasu.
examples.kanji: スミス 先[せん]生[せい]は 日[に]本[ほん]文[ぶん]学[がく]を研[けん]究[きゅう]しています。
examples.translation: Prof. Smith is studying Japanese literature.

description.romaji: In contrast to Vte iru (1), which expresses an ongoing action, Vte iru (2) expresses a state of being resulting from a previous action. Typical Japanese verbs that use this form are shiru (learn, realize or know), motsu (possess) and oboeru (remember). In this Vte iru form, these verbs indicate states of "knowing," "possessing" or "remembering," usually represented in English by, in the first person, "I know," "I have" and "I remember." Note that the opposite of shitteiru is shiranai (not shitte inai).
description.kanji: In contrast to Vte いる (1), which expresses an ongoing action, Vte いる (2) expresses a state of being resulting from a previous action. Typical Japanese verbs that use this form are 知[し]る (learn, realize or know), 持[も]つ (possess) and 覚[おぼ]える (remember). In this Vte いる form, these verbs indicate states of "knowing," "possessing" or "remembering," usually represented in English by, in the first person, "I know," "I have" and "I remember." Note that the opposite of 知[し]っている is 知[し]らない (not 知[し]っていない).

examples.romaji: Ginkō wa sanji made aite iru.
examples.kanji: 銀[ぎん]行[こう]は 三[さん]時[じ]まで開[あ]いている。
examples.translation: The bank is open until three o'clock.

examples.romaji: Toda-san wa akai doresu o kite imasu.
examples.kanji: 戸[と]田[だ]さんは 赤[あか]いドレスを着[き]ています。
examples.translation: Ms. Toda is wearing a red dress.

examples.romaji: Hara-san wa kekkon shite iru.
examples.kanji: 原[はら]さんは結[けっ]婚[こん]している。
examples.translation: Mr. Hara is married.

description.romaji: Like Vte iru (2), Vte aru expresses a state of being resulting from a previous action. In this form, only transitive verbs are used and the subject of the sentence is always inanimate. In the Vte aru form, there is an implication that someone did the action, therefore the resulting state exists. On the other hand, in the Vte iru form, there is no such implication but a mere description of fact.
description.kanji: Like Vte いる (2), Vte ある expresses a state of being resulting from a previous action. In this form, only transitive verbs are used and the subject of the sentence is always inanimate. In the Vte ある form, there is an implication that someone did the action, therefore the resulting state exists. On the other hand, in the Vte いる form, there is no such implication but a mere description of fact.

examples.romaji: Kono taoru wa tsukatte arimasu.
examples.kanji: このタオルは使[つか]ってあります。
examples.translation: This towel has been used.

examples.romaji: Kyōshitsu no doa ga shimete aru.
examples.kanji: 教[きょう]室[しつ]のドアが閉[し]めてある。
examples.translation: The door of the classroom is closed.

examples.romaji: Kono terebi wa shūri shite arimasu.
examples.kanji: このテレビは修[しゅう]理[り]してあります。
examples.translation: This TV set has been repaired.

description.romaji: Expresses the time relationship (after/since) between actions or events.
description.kanji: Expresses the time relationship (after/since) between actions or events.

examples.romaji: Kono apāto ni utsutte kara sannen ni naru.
examples.kanji: このアパートに移[うつ]ってから 三[さん]年[ねん]になる。
examples.translation: It's been three years since I moved into this apartment.

examples.romaji: Shukudai o sumasete kara asobinasai.
examples.kanji: 宿[しゅく]題[だい]を済[す]ませてから 遊[あそ]びなさい。
examples.translation: Play after you finish your homework.

examples.romaji: Watashi wa daigaku o sotsugyō shite kara ginkō de hataraku tsumori desu.
examples.kanji: 私[わたし]は 大[だい]学[がく]を卒[そつ]業[ぎょう]してから 銀[ぎん]行[こう]で 働[はたら]くつもりです。
examples.translation: I intend to work in a bank after graduating from college.

description.romaji: Expresses the only action that a person is doing.
description.kanji: Expresses the only action that a person is doing.

examples.romaji: Tonari no otoko no ko wa ichinichijū hāmonika o fuite bakari iru.
examples.kanji: 隣[となり]の 男[おとこ]の 子[こ]は 一[いち]日[にち]中[じゅう]ハーモニカを吹[ふ]いてばかりいる。
examples.translation: The boy next door does nothing but play a harmonica all day long.

examples.romaji: Yoshiko-san wa shigoto o kaete bakari imasu.
examples.kanji: 良[よし]子[こ]さんは 仕[し]事[ごと]を変[ka]えてばかりいます。
examples.translation: Yoshiko does nothing but change jobs.

examples.romaji: Mizuki-san wa dōryō to giron shite bakari iru.
examples.kanji: 水[みず]木[き]さんは 同[どう]僚[りょう]と議[ぎ]論[ろん]してばかりいる。
examples.translation: Mr. Mizuki does nothing but argue with his colleagues.

description.romaji: Expresses a desire to have someone (marked by the particle ni) do something. This someone is not supposed to be higher in status than the speaker. This pattern is used with the first person in declarative sentences (Example 1) and with the second person in interrogative sentences (Example 2).
description.kanji: Expresses a desire to have someone (marked by the particle に) do something. This someone is not supposed to be higher in status than the speaker. This pattern is used with the first person in declarative sentences (Example 1) and with the second person in interrogative sentences (Example 2).

examples.romaji: Watashi wa Minami-san ni kono tegami o yonde hoshii.
examples.kanji: 私[わたし]は 南[みなみ]さんにこの 手[て]紙[がみ]を読[よ]んでほしい。
examples.translation: I want Miss Minami to read this letter.

examples.romaji: Anata wa dare ni NIhongo o oshiete hoshii desu ka.
examples.kanji: あなたはだれに 日[に]本[ほん]語[ご]を教[おし]えてほしいですか。
examples.translation: Who do you want to teach you Japanese?

examples.romaji: Hoteru no yoyaku o kakunin shite hoshii desu.
examples.kanji: ホテルの 予[よ]約[やく]を確[かく]認[にん]してほしいです。
examples.translation: I want you to confirm the reservation at the hotel.

description.romaji: Used as a conjunction to express a condition.
description.kanji: Used as a conjunction to express a condition.

examples.romaji: Hiroshi wa sankōsho o katte mo tsukaimasen.
examples.kanji: 宏[ひろし]は 参[さん]考[こう]書[しょ]を買[か]っても 使[つか]いません。
examples.translation: Hiroshi doesn't use reference books, even if he buys them.

examples.romaji: Kono kotoba wa jisho de shirabete mo wakarimasen deshita.
examples.kanji: この 言[こと]葉[ば]は 辞[じ]書[しょ]で調[しら]べても 分[わ]かりませんでした。
examples.translation: Although I checked this word in the dictionary, I couldn't understand it.

examples.romaji: Kare wa yakusoku shite mo mamoranai.
examples.kanji: 彼[かれ]は約[やく]束[そく]しても 守[まも]らない。
examples.translation: Even if he promises, he doesn't keep it.

description.romaji: Expresses permission or concession.
description.kanji: Expresses permission or concession.

examples.romaji: Koko de wa tabako o sutte mo ii desu.
examples.kanji: ここではたばこを吸[す]ってもいいです。
examples.translation: It is all right if you smoke here.

examples.romaji: Koko ni kuruma o tomete mo ii desu ka.
examples.kanji: ここに 車[くるま]を止[と]めてもいいですか。
examples.translation: May I park the car here?

examples.romaji: Kono kisoku wa haishi shite mo ii to omou.
examples.kanji: この 規[き]則[そく]は廃[はい]止[し]してもいいと 思[おも]う。
examples.translation: I think that we can abolish this regulation.

description.romaji: Expresses a condition with a set of affirmative and negative verb forms. The second verb may be affirmative if it has an opposite meaning to the first verb (Example 3).
description.kanji: Expresses a condition with a set of affirmative and negative verb forms. The second verb may be affirmative if it has an opposite meaning to the first verb (Example 3).

examples.romaji: Ame ga futte mo furanakute mo iku.
examples.kanji: 雨[あめ]が降[ふ]っても降[ふ]らなくても 行[い]く。
examples.translation: I'll go whether it rains or not.

examples.romaji: Kono shigoto wa tanomarete mo tanomarenakute mo watashi ga yaru.
examples.kanji: この 仕[し]事[ごと]は頼[たの]まれても頼[たの]まれなくても 私[わたし]がやる。
examples.translation: I myself will do this work whether asked or not.

examples.romaji: Honda-san ga kaigi ni shusseki shite mo kesseki shite mo kamaimasen.
examples.kanji: 本[ほん]田[だ]さんが 会[かい]議[ぎ]に出[しゅっ]席[せき]しても欠[けっ]席[せき]してもかまいません。
examples.translation: It doesn't matter whether Mr. Honda attends the meeting or not.

conjugation.translation:
• "It is not all right if"
  • "must not"

description.romaji: Expresses prohibition. Ikemasen is the polite style. The verb komaru (be problematic) may be used in place of ikenai.
description.kanji: Expresses prohibition. いけません is the polite style. The verb 困[こま]る (be problematic) may be used in place of いけない.

examples.romaji: Rōka o hashitte wa ikenai.
examples.kanji: 廊[ろう]下[か]を走[はし]ってはいけない。
examples.translation: You must not run in the corridor.

examples.romaji: Shukudai o wasurete wa komarimasu.
examples.kanji: 宿[しゅく]題[だい]を忘[わす]れては 困[こま]ります。
examples.translation: You must not forget your homework.

examples.romaji: Kare no kotoba o gokai shite wa ikemasen.
examples.kanji: 彼[かれ]の 言[こと]葉[ば]を誤[ご]解[かい]してはいけません。
examples.translation: You must not misunderstand his words.

description.romaji: Expresses a person's doing a favorable action for someone whose status is about equal to that of the doer (Example 1). Vte sashiageru is used for someone whose status is higher than that of the doer (Example 2). Vte yaru is used for someone whose status is lower than that of the doer or who is a close friend of the doer. The verbs ageru, sashiageru and yaru (give) are used as auxiliaries. The indirect object (the receiver of the favorable action marked by the particle ni) cannot be the first person.
description.kanji: Expresses a person's doing a favorable action for someone whose status is about equal to that of the doer (Example 1). Vte さしあげる is used for someone whose status is higher than that of the doer (Example 2). Vte やる is used for someone whose status is lower than that of the doer or who is a close friend of the doer. The verbs あげる, さしあげる and やる (give) are used as auxiliaries. The indirect object (the receiver of the favorable action marked by the particle に) cannot be the first person.

examples.romaji: Watashi wa Haruko-san ni konsāto no kippu o katte agemashita.
examples.kanji: 私[わたし]は 春[はる]子[こ]さんにコンサートの 切[きっ]符[ぷ]を買[か]ってあげました。
examples.translation: I bought a concert ticket for Haruko.

examples.romaji: Watashi wa sensei ni shashin o misete sashiagemashita.
examples.kanji: 私[わたし]は 先[せん]生[せい]に 写[しゃ]真[しん]を見[み]せてさしあげました。
examples.translation: I showed the photos to my teacher.

examples.romaji: Watashi wa imōto ni sentaku shite yarimashita.
examples.kanji: 私[わたし]は 妹[いもうと]に洗[せん]濯[たく]してやりました。
examples.translation: I washed clothes for my younger sister.

description.romaji: Indicates that a person receives a favorable action from someone whose status is about equal to or lower than that of the receiver. Vte itadaku is used when the favorable action comes from someone whose status is higher than that of the receiver (Example 2). The verbs morau and itadaku (receive) are used as auxiliaries. The indirect object (the doer of the favorable action marked by the particle ni) cannot be the first person.
description.kanji: Indicates that a person receives a favorable action from someone whose status is about equal to or lower than that of the receiver. Vte いただく is used when the favorable action comes from someone whose status is higher than that of the receiver (Example 2). The verbs もらう and いただく (receive) are used as auxiliaries. The indirect object (the doer of the favorable action marked by the particle に) cannot be the first person.

examples.romaji: Toda-san wa tokidoki Ogawa-san ni kuruma o aratte morau.
examples.kanji: 戸[と]田[だ]さんは 時[とき]々[どき]小[お]川[がわ]さんに 車[くるま]を洗[あら]ってもらう。
examples.translation: Ms. Toda sometimes has Mr. Ogawa wash the car for her.

examples.romaji: Watashi-tachi wa Takagi-sensei ni kanji o oshiete itadakimasu.
examples.kanji: 私[わたし]達[たち]は 高[たか]木[ぎ]先[せん]生[せい]に 漢[かん]字[じ]を教[おし]えていただきます。
examples.translation: We have Prof. Takagi teach us kanji. (Prof. Takagi teaches us kanji.)

examples.romaji: Watashi wa tomodachi ni machi o annai shite moraimashita.
examples.kanji: 私[わたし]は 友[とも]達[だち]に 町[まち]を案[あん]内[ない]してもらいました。
examples.translation: I had my friend show me the town.

description.romaji: Indicates that someone is doing a favorable action for the speaker (the first person) or someone who is close to the speaker. Vte kudasaru is used when the status of the doer of the favorable action is higher than that of the receiver (Example 3). The verbs kureru and kudasaru (give) are used as auxiliaries.
description.kanji: Indicates that someone is doing a favorable action for the speaker (the first person) or someone who is close to the speaker. Vte くださる is used when the status of the doer of the favorable action is higher than that of the receiver (Example 3). The verbs くれる and くださる (give) are used as auxiliaries.

examples.romaji: Tokidoki ane ga (watashi ni) kukkī o yaite kureru.
examples.kanji: 時[とき]々[どき]姉[あね]が（ 私[わたし]に）クッキーを焼[や]いてくれる。
examples.translation: Once in a while my older sister bakes cookies for me.

examples.romaji: Dare ga (anata ni) sono nyūsu o shirasete kuremashita ka.
examples.kanji: だれが（あなたに）そのニュースを知[し]らせてくれましたか。
examples.translation: Who informed you of the news?

examples.romaji: Hara-sensei ga (watashi-tachi ni) jisho no tsukaikata o setsumei shite kudasaimashita.
examples.kanji: 原[はら]先[せん]生[せい]が（ 私[わたし]達[たち]に） 辞[じ]書[しょ]の 使[つか]い 方[かた]を説[せつ]明[めい]してくださいました。
examples.translation: Prof. Hara explained to us how to use the dictionary.

description.romaji: Expresses the time when an action or event is/was taking place. Toki (time) is used as a pseudo noun and functions as a conjunction. The tense of the sentence is determined by the verb in the main clause.
description.kanji: Expresses the time when an action or event is/was taking place. 時[とき] (time) is used as a pseudo noun and functions as a conjunction. The tense of the sentence is determined by the verb in the main clause.

examples.romaji: Watashi ga Yamada-san to hanashite iru toki (ni), kozutsumi ga todokimashita.
examples.kanji: 私[わたし]が 山[やま]田[だ]さんと話[はな]している 時[とき]（に）、 小[こ]包[づつみ]が 届[とど]きました。
examples.translation: While I was talking with Mrs. Yamada, a package arrived.

examples.romaji: Asagohan o tabete iru toki (ni), denwa ga narimashita.
examples.kanji: 朝[あさ]ご 飯[はん]を食[た]べている 時[とき]（に）、 電[でん]話[わ]が 鳴[な]りました。
examples.translation: While I was eating breakfast, the telephone rang.

examples.romaji: Kare wa itsumo watashi ga benkyō shite iru toki (ni) kuru.
examples.kanji: 彼[かれ]はいつも 私[わたし]が勉[べん]強[きょう]している 時[とき]（に）、 来[く]る。
examples.translation: He always comes when I am studying.

description.romaji: Expresses the time during which an action or event is/was taking place. Aida without ni indicates that the two actions or events in the main clause and subordinate clause (the aida-clause) cover the same span of time (Examples 1, 2). Aida with ni indicates that an action or event in the main clause occurs within the time span of an action or event in the aida-clause (Example 3).
description.kanji: Expresses the time during which an action or event is/was taking place. 間[あいだ] without に indicates that the two actions or events in the main clause and subordinate clause (the 間[あいだ]-clause) cover the same span of time (Examples 1, 2). 間[あいだ] with に indicates that an action or event in the main clause occurs within the time span of an action or event in the 間[あいだ]-clause (Example 3).

examples.romaji: Samu wa sensei ga hanashite iru aida hon o yonde imashita.
examples.kanji: サムは 先[せん]生[せい]が話[はな]している 間[あいだ]本[ほん]を 読[よ]んでいました。
examples.translation: Sam was reading a book while the teacher was talking.

examples.romaji: Kodomo ga ehon mite iru aida watashi wa kēki o yaite imashita.
examples.kanji: 子[こ]供[ども]が 絵[え]本[ほん]見[み]ている 間[あいだ]私[わたし]はケーキを 焼[や]いていました。
examples.translation: I was baking a cake while my child was looking at a picture book.

examples.romaji: Kida-san ga shutchō shite iru aida ni o-tōsan ga nakunarimashita.
examples.kanji: 木[き]田[だ]さんが出[しゅっ]張[ちょう]している 間[あいだ]にお 父[とう]さんが 亡[な]くなりました。
examples.translation: While Mr. Kida was on a business trip, his father passed away.

description.romaji: Expresses the time during which an action or event is/was taking place. This pattern may be replaced by Vte iru aida ni.
description.kanji: Expresses the time during which an action or event is/was taking place. This pattern may be replaced by Vte いる 間[あいだ]に.

examples.romaji: Kare o matte iru uchi ni kanji o oboemashita.
examples.kanji: 彼[かれ]を待[ま]っているうちに 漢[かん]字[じ]を 覚[おぼ]えました。
examples.translation: I memorized kanji while waiting for him.

examples.romaji: Kodomo ga nete iru uchi ni hon o yomu.
examples.kanji: 子[こ]供[ども]が寝[ね]ているうちに 本[ほん]を 読[よ]む。
examples.translation: I read books while my child is sleeping.

examples.romaji: Sanpo shite iru uchi ni ame ga furihajimemashita.
examples.kanji: 散[さん]歩[ぽ]しているうちに 雨[あめ]が 降[ふ]り 始[はじ]めました。
examples.translation: It started to rain while I was taking a stroll.

description.romaji: Used as a modifier of the following noun, e.g. asonde iru kodomo (a child who is playing); hako ni irete aru hon (the books put in the box).
description.kanji: Used as a modifier of the following noun, e.g. 遊[あそ]んでいる 子供[こども] (a child who is playing); 箱[はこ]に 入[い]れてある 本[ほん] (the books put in the box).

examples.romaji: Asoko ni tatte iru hito wa dare desu ka.
examples.kanji: あそこに立[た]っている 人[ひと]はだれですか。
examples.translation: Who is the person standing over there?

examples.romaji: Ano megane o kakete iru otoko no hito ga watashi-tachi no sensei desu.
examples.kanji: あの 眼[め]鏡[がね]をかけている 男[おとこ]の 人[ひと]が 私[わたし]達[たち]の 先[せん]生[せい]です。
examples.translation: The man who is wearing glasses is our teacher.

examples.romaji: Shūri shite aru terebi wa asoko ni oite aru.
examples.kanji: 修[しゅう]理[り]してあるテレビはあそこにおいてある。
examples.translation: The TV sets which have been repaired have been put over there.

description.romaji: Expresses a person's attempt at doing something to see what it is like. The verb miru (see) is used as an auxiliary.
description.kanji: Expresses a person's attempt at doing something to see what it is like. The verb みる (see) is used as an auxiliary.

examples.romaji: Akira wa hajimete bīru o nonde mimashita.
examples.kanji: 明[あきら]は 初[はじ]めてビールを飲[の]んでみました。
examples.translation: Akira drank beer for the first time (to see what it is like).

examples.romaji: Rainen ano yama o kuruma de koete mimasu.
examples.kanji: 来[らい]年[ねん]あの 山[やま]を 車[くるま]で超[こ]えてみます。
examples.translation: I'll try to cross that mountain by car next year.

examples.romaji: Kono keikaku o jikkō shite miru tsumori da.
examples.kanji: この 計[けい]画[かく]を実[じっ]行[こう]してみるつもりだ。
examples.translation: I intend to try to put this plan into practice.

description.romaji: Expresses an action which goes away from the location of the speaker or moves into the future. The verb iku (go) is used as an auxiliary.
description.kanji: Expresses an action which goes away from the location of the speaker or moves into the future. The verb いく (go) is used as an auxiliary.

examples.romaji: Tori ga tonde iku.
examples.kanji: 鳥[とり]が飛[と]んでいく。
examples.translation: Birds are flying away.

examples.romaji: Dorobō ga achira e nigete ikimashita.
examples.kanji: 泥[どろ]棒[ぼう]があちらへ逃[に]げていきました。
examples.translation: The thief escaped in that direction.

examples.romaji: Kono machi wa henka shite iku deshō.
examples.kanji: この 町[まち]は変[へん]化[か]していくでしょう。
examples.translation: This town probably will go on changing.

description.romaji: Expresses an action which comes toward the location of the speaker or up to a current point of time. The verb kuru (come) is used as an auxiliary.
description.kanji: Expresses an action which comes toward the location of the speaker or up to a current point of time. The verb くる (come) is used as an auxiliary.

examples.romaji: Kyū ni tsuyoi kaze ga fuite kimashita.
examples.kanji: 急[きゅう]に 強[つよ]い 風[かぜ]が吹[ふ]いてきました。
examples.translation: Suddenly a strong wind began to blow.

examples.romaji: Ōkii hako ga kaigan ni nagarete kimashita.
examples.kanji: 大[おお]きい 箱[はこ]が 海[かい]岸[がん]に流[なが]れてきました。
examples.translation: A big box drifted to the seashore.

examples.romaji: Niwa no wakagi ga seichō shite kimashita.
examples.kanji: 庭[にわ]の 若[わか]木[ぎ]が成[せい]長[ちょう]してきました。
examples.translation: The young trees in the garden have grown.

description.romaji: Expresses an action which is performed in advance for future convenience. The verb oku (put) is used as an auxiliary.
description.kanji: Expresses an action which is performed in advance for future convenience. The verb おく (put) is used as an auxiliary.

examples.romaji: Tomodachi ga kuru kara, o-kashi o katte oku.
examples.kanji: 友[とも]達[だち]が 来[く]るから、お 菓[か]子[し]を買[か]っておく。
examples.translation: Because my friends are coming, I'll buy some sweets.

examples.romaji: Kaigi ga hajimaru mae ni mō ichido shorui o shirabete okimashita.
examples.kanji: 会[かい]議[ぎ]が 始[はじ]まる 前[まえ]にもう 一[いち]度[ど]書[しょ]類[るい]を調[しら]べておきました。
examples.translation: Before the meeting began, I had checked the document once more.

examples.romaji: Kore wa nedan ga agaranai uchi ni, sugu chūmon shite okimashō.
examples.kanji: これは 値[ね]段[だん]が 上[あ]がらないうちに、すぐ注[ちゅう]文[もん]しておきましょう。
examples.translation: Let's order this right away, before the price goes up.

description.romaji: Expresses with emphasis the completion of an action and, in some cases, may imply a sense of regret for an action being totally completed (Example 2). The verb shimau (finish or put away) is used as an auxiliary.
description.kanji: Expresses with emphasis the completion of an action and, in some cases, may imply a sense of regret for an action being totally completed (Example 2). The verb しまう (finish or put away) is used as an auxiliary.

examples.romaji: Sono koto wa mō sensei ni hanashite shimaimashita.
examples.kanji: そのことはもう 先[せん]生[せい]に話[はな]してしまいました。
examples.translation: I have already spoken to my teacher about that matter.

examples.romaji: Jimu wa sengatsu gakkō o yamete shimaimashita.
examples.kanji: ジムは 先[せん]月[がつ]学[がっ]校[こう]を辞[や]めてしまいました。
examples.translation: Jim quit school last month (to my regret).

examples.romaji: Raigetsujū ni kono purojekuto o kansei shite shimaō to omou.
examples.kanji: 来[らい]月[げつ]中[じゅう]にこのプロジェクトを完[かん]成[せい]してしまおうと 思[おも]う。
examples.translation: I think that I will finish up this project within the next month.

description.romaji: Past tense of Vdic. Expresses actions or states which have taken place/took place or existed. This form is used for the plain style.
description.kanji: Past tense of Vdic. Expresses actions or states which have taken place/took place or existed. This form is used for the plain style.

examples.romaji: Kare wa sono shashin o mite ōkii koe de waratta.
examples.kanji: 彼[かれ]はその 写[しゃ]真[しん]を 見[み]て 大[おお]きい 声[こえ]で笑[わら]った。
examples.translation: Looking at the picture, he laughed loudly.

examples.romaji: Sensei wa gakusei o mittsu no gurūpu ni waketa.
examples.kanji: 先[せん]生[せい]は 学[がく]生[せい]を 三[みっ]つのグループに分[わ]けた。
examples.translation: The teacher divided the students into three groups.

examples.romaji: Machi no jinkō ga nibai ni zōka shita.
examples.kanji: 町[まち]の 人[じん]口[こう]が 二[に]倍[ばい]に増[ぞう]加[か]した。
examples.translation: The population of the city increased by two times.

description.romaji: Expresses the speaker's conviction about having done something.
description.kanji: Expresses the speaker's conviction about having done something.

examples.romaji: Sono shorui wa senjitsu Noda-san ni watashita tsumori da.
examples.kanji: その 書[しょ]類[るい]は 先[せん]日[じつ]野[の]田[だ]さんに渡[わた]したつもりだ。
examples.translation: I'm convinced that I handed the documents to Mr. Noda the other day.

examples.romaji: Watashi wa Hara-san to no yakusoku no jikan o kaeta tsumori datta.
examples.kanji: 私[わたし]は 原[はら]さんとの 約[やく]束[そく]の 時[じ]間[かん]を変[か]えたつもりだった。
examples.translation: I was convinced that I had changed the appointment time with Miss Hara.

examples.romaji: Sono ken wa kono mae no kaigi de hōkoku shita tsumori desu.
examples.kanji: その 件[けん]はこの 前[まえ]の 会[かい]議[ぎ]で報[ほう]告[こく]したつもりです。
examples.translation: I'm convinced that I reported on that matter in the last meeting.

description.romaji: Expresses the speaker's feeling or certainty that something took place.
description.kanji: Expresses the speaker's feeling or certainty that something took place.

examples.romaji: Fukeiki de uriage ga hetta hazu desu.
examples.kanji: 不[ふ]景[けい]気[き]で 売[う]り 上[あ]げが減[へ]ったはずです。
examples.translation: It is felt that sales decreased due to the recession.

examples.romaji: Kare wa sono ban uchi ni ita hazu da.
examples.kanji: 彼[かれ]はその 晩[ばん]うちにいたはずだ。
examples.translation: I expect (I'm quite sure) that he was at home on that night.

examples.romaji: Tamura-san wa kyonen intai shita hazu desu.
examples.kanji: 田[た]村[むら]さんは 去[きょ]年[ねん]引[いん]退[たい]したはずです。
examples.translation: I am quite sure that Mr. Tamura retired last year.

description.romaji: Expresses the speaker's conjecture about past actions or events.
description.kanji: Expresses the speaker's conjecture about past actions or events.

examples.romaji: Kimura-san no ryokō n yotei wa mō kimatta darō.
examples.kanji: 木[き]村[むら]さんの 旅[りょ]行[こう]の 予[よ]定[てい]はもう決[き]まっただろう。
examples.translation: Miss Kimura's travel plans have probably been decided by now.

examples.romaji: Kyonen no jishin de ano tatemono wa kowareta deshō.
examples.kanji: 去[きょ]年[ねん]の 地[じ]震[しん]であの 建[たて]物[もの]は壊[こわ]れたでしょう。
examples.translation: That building was probably destroyed by last year's earthquake.

examples.romaji: Honkon kara no hikōki wa ichijikan mae ni tōchaku shita darō.
examples.kanji: 香[ほん]港[こん]からの 飛[ひ]行[こう]機[き]は 一[いち]時[じ]間[かん]前[まえ]に到[とう]着[ちゃく]しただろう。
examples.translation: The plane from Hong Kong probably arrived one hour ago.

description.romaji: Expresses the speaker's speculation or guess about past actions or events.
description.kanji: Expresses the speaker's speculation or guess about past actions or events.

examples.romaji: Buraun-san wa Ginza de michi ni mayotta kamoshirenai.
examples.kanji: ブラウンさんは 銀[ぎん]座[ざ]で 道[みち]に迷[まよ]ったかもしれない。
examples.translation: Mr. Brown might have lost his way in Ginza.

examples.romaji: Tanaka-san wa kyō no yakusoku o wasureta kamoshiremasen.
examples.kanji: 田[た]中[なか]さんは 今日[きょう]の 約[やく]束[そく]を忘[わす]れたかもしれません。
examples.translation: Miss Tanaka might have forgotten today's appointment.

examples.romaji: Kaisha ga hiyō o futan shita kamoshirenai.
examples.kanji: 会[かい]社[しゃ]が 費[ひ]用[よう]を負[ふ]担[たん]したかもしれない。
examples.translation: The company might have born the expense.

description.romaji: Expresses with confidence the speaker's guess about past actions or events.
description.kanji: Expresses with confidence the speaker's guess about past actions or events.

examples.romaji: Dare ka kono heya de tabako o sutta ni chigainai.
examples.kanji: だれかこの 部[へ]屋[や]でたばこを吸[す]ったにちがいない。
examples.translation: Someone must have been smoking in this room.

examples.romaji: Nete iru aida ni denki ga kieta ni chigai arimasen.
examples.kanji: 寝[ね]ている 間あいだ]に 電[でん]気[き]が消[き]えたにちがいありません。
examples.translation: The electricity must have gone off while I was sleeping.

examples.romaji: Ano kaisha wa tōsan shita ni chigai arimasen.
examples.kanji: あの 会[かい]社[しゃ]は倒[とう]産[さん]したにちがいありません。
examples.translation: There is no doubt that the company went bankrupt.

description.romaji: Both no and koto are nominalizers. Vta no/koto expresses a noun phrase.
description.kanji: Both の and こと are nominalizers. Vta の・こと expresses a noun phrase.

examples.romaji: Saifu o otoshita no/koto ni kizukimasen deshita.
examples.kanji: 財[さい]布[ふ]を落[お]としたの・ことに 気[き]づきませんでした。
examples.translation: I was not aware that I had lost my wallet.

examples.romaji: Waga chīmu ga kesshōsen de maketa no/koto wa jitsu ni zannen da.
examples.kanji: 我[わ]がチームが 決[けっ]勝[しょう]戦[せん]で負[ま]けたの・ことは 実[じつ]に 残[ざん]念[ねん]だ。
examples.translation: It is truly regrettable that our team lost in the final game.

examples.romaji: Keisatsu ga hannin o taiho shita no/koto o shitte imasu ka.
examples.kanji: 警[けい]察[さつ]が 犯[はん]人[にん]を逮[たい]捕[ほ]したの・ことを 知[し]っていますか。
examples.translation: Are you aware that the police arrested the criminal?

description.romaji: Expresses a person's experience.
description.kanji: Expresses a person's experience.

examples.romaji: Watashi wa nando mo Chūgoku e itta koto ga aru.
examples.kanji: 私[わたし]は 何[なん]度[ど]も 中[ちゅう]国[ごく]へ行[い]ったことがある。
examples.translation: I have been to China many times.

examples.romaji: Harisu-san wa Tōkyō no daigaku de Eigo o oshieta koto ga arimasu.
examples.kanji: ハリスさんは 東[とう]京[きょう]の 大[だい]学[がく]で 英[えい]語[ご]を教[おし]えたことがあります。
examples.translation: Ms. Harris has taught English at a university in Tokyo.

examples.romaji: Kare wa yasei dōbutsu no seitai o kansatsu shita koto ga aru.
examples.kanji: 彼[かれ]は 野[や]生[せい]動[どう]物[ぶつ]の 生[せい]態[たい]を観[かん]察[さつ]したことがある。
examples.translation: He has had the experience of observing the life of wild animals.

description.romaji: Expresses an action which has just been completed.
description.kanji: Expresses an action which has just been completed.

examples.romaji: Ima repōto o kakiowatta tokoro da.
examples.kanji: 今[いま]レポートを書[か]き 終[お]わったところだ。
examples.translation: I have just finished writing the report.

examples.romaji: Haha wa kaimono ni dekaketa tokoro desu.
examples.kanji: 母[はは]は 買[か]い 物[もの]に出[で]かけたところです。
examples.translation: My mother has just left for shopping.

examples.romaji: Yamamoto-san ikka wa Hokkaidō ni iten shita tokoro desu.
examples.kanji: 山[やま]本[もと]さん 一[いっ]家[か]は 北[ほっ]海[かい]道[どう]に移[い]転[てん]したところです。
examples.translation: The Yamamoto family has just moved to Hokkaido.

description.romaji: Expresses advice to do something.
description.kanji: Expresses advice to do something.

examples.romaji: Kuraku naranai uchi ni kaetta hō ga ii.
examples.kanji: 暗[くら]くならないうちに帰[かえ]ったほうがいい。
examples.translation: You had better go home before it gets dark.

examples.romaji: Kono shigoto wa ashita made ni sumaseta hō ga ii desu ka.
examples.kanji: この 仕[し]事[ごと]は 明日[あした]までに済[す]ませたほうがいいですか。
examples.translation: Should I finish this work by tomorrow?

examples.romaji: Kimura-san wa shibaraku kinshu shita hō ga ii desu.
examples.kanji: 木[き]村[むら]さんはしばらく禁[きん]酒[しゅ]したほうがいいです。
examples.translation: Mr. Kimura had better quit drinking for a while.

description.romaji: Expresses a past action or event which is followed by a result contrary to expectation.
description.kanji: Expresses a past action or event which is followed by a result contrary to expectation.

examples.romaji: Ayamatta noni kare wa mada okotte iru.
examples.kanji: 謝[あやま]ったのに 彼[かれ]はまだ 怒[おこ]っている。
examples.translation: Although I apologized to him, he is still angry.

examples.romaji: Yakusoku no jikan ga sugita noni Oda-san wa mada konai.
examples.kanji: 約[やく]束[そく]の 時[じ]間[かん]が過[す]ぎたのに 小[お]田[だ]さんはまだ 来[こ]ない。
examples.translation: Although it is past the appointment time, Mr. Oda hasn't come yet.

examples.romaji: Kare wa daigaku ni nyūgaku shita noni ichinen de yamete shimaimashita.
examples.kanji: 彼[かれ]は 大[だい]学[がく]に入[にゅう]学[がく]したのに 一[いち]年[ねん]で 辞[や]めてしまいました。
examples.translation: In spite of the fact that he got into college, he quit in one year (to my regret).

description.romaji: Expresses a supposition or condition about past actions or events.
description.kanji: Expresses a supposition or condition about past actions or events.

examples.romaji: Heya ga aita (no) nara sugu utsuritai.
examples.kanji: 部[へ]屋[や]が空[あ]いた（の）ならすぐ 移[うつ]りたい。
examples.translation: If the room has been vacated, I'd like to move in right away.

examples.romaji: Benkyō ni akita (no) nara sukoshi yasuminasai.
examples.kanji: 勉[べん]強[きょう]に飽[あ]きた（の）なら 少[すこ]し 休[やす]みなさい。
examples.translation: If you get tired of studying, take a short break.

examples.romaji: Ikeda-san ga kōshō shita (no) nara banji umaku iku deshō.
examples.kanji: 池[いけ]田[だ]さんが交[こう]渉[しょう]した（の）なら 万[ばん]事[じ]うまく 行[い]くでしょう。
examples.translation: If Mr. Ikeda has conducted the negotiations, everything should go well.

conjugation.translation: • "(I don't know/can't tell) when, what, etc."

description.romaji: An interrogative (with or without a particle) followed by Vta ka expresses a question about past actions or events embedded in a sentence.
description.kanji: An interrogative (with or without a particle) followed by Vta か expresses a question about past actions or events embedded in a sentence.

examples.romaji: Kinō no shiai de dochira ga katta ka shiranai.
examples.kanji: 昨日[きのう]の 試[し]合[あい]でどちらが勝[か]ったか 知[し]らない。
examples.translation: I don't know which one won yesterday's game.

examples.romaji: Yūbe Wada-san to nanji ni wakareta ka oboete imasen.
examples.kanji: ゆうべ 和[わ]田[だ]さんと 何[なん]時[じ]に別[わか]れたか 覚[おぼ]えていません。
examples.translation: I don't remember what time I parted from Mr. Wada last night.

examples.romaji: Hara-san ga itsu tenkin shita ka wakaranai.
examples.kanji: 原[はら]さんがいつ転[てん]勤[きん]したか 分[わ]からない。
examples.translation: I can't say when Mr. Hara was transferred.

conjugation.translation: • "(I don't know/can't tell) whether or not"

description.romaji: Expresses a question about past actions or events embedded in a sentence.
description.kanji: Expresses a question about past actions or events embedded in a sentence.

examples.romaji: Mō sakura no hana ga chitta ka dō ka shirimasen.
examples.kanji: もう 桜[さくら]の 花[はな]が散[ち]ったかどうか 知[し]りません。
examples.translation: I don't know whether the cherry blossoms have fallen or not.

examples.romaji: Kanojo ga kare o akirameta ka dō ka shiranai.
examples.kanji: 彼[かの]女[じょ]が 彼[かれ]をあきらめたかどうか 知[し]らない。
examples.translation: I don't know whether she gave him up or not.

examples.romaji: Matsui-san ga atarashii jigyō ni seikō shita ka dō ka wakarimasen.
examples.kanji: 松[まつ]井[い]さんが 新[あたら]しい 事[じ]業[ぎょう]に成[せい]功[こう]したかどうか 分[わ]かりません。
examples.translation: I can't tell whether Mr. Matsui has succeeded in his new enterprise.

description.romaji: Expresses a cause or reason for past actions or events personally interpreted by the speaker.
description.kanji: Expresses a cause or reason for past actions or events personally interpreted by the speaker.

examples.romaji: Kēki o tsukutta kara tabete kudasai.
examples.kanji: ケーキを作[つく]ったから 食[た]べてください。
examples.translation: I made a cake, so please eat it.

examples.romaji: Ii resutoran o eranda kara chūshokukai wa tanoshikatta.
examples.kanji: いいレストランを選[えら]んだから 昼[ちゅう]食[しょく]会[かい]は 楽[たの]しかった。
examples.translation: Because we chose a good restaurant, our luncheon (party) was enjoyable.

examples.romaji: Kare wa tōshi ni shippai shita kara gakkari shite imasu.
examples.kanji: 彼[かれ]は 投[とう]資[し]に失[しっ]敗[ぱい]したからがっかりしています。
examples.translation: Since he failed in the investment, he is disheartened.

description.romaji: Expresses a cause or reason for past actions or events presented more objectively, without projecting the speaker's personal opinion.
description.kanji: Expresses a cause or reason for past actions or events presented more objectively, without projecting the speaker's personal opinion.

examples.romaji: Kuruma no jiko ga atta node ano michi wa tōrenai.
examples.kanji: 車[くるま]の 事[じ]故[こ]があったのであの 道[みち]は 通[とお]れない。
examples.translation: Because there was a car accident, you can't go along that road.

examples.romaji: Kanojo wa hatarakisugita node byōki ni narimashita.
examples.kanji: 彼[かの]女[じょ]は働[はたら]きすぎたので 病[びょう]気[き]になりました。
examples.translation: She worked too hard, so she got sick.

examples.romaji: Yūbe teiden shita node benkyō dekinakatta.
examples.kanji: ゆうべ停[てい]電[でん]したので 勉[べん]強[きょう]出[で]来[き]なかった。
examples.translation: I couldn't study last night, because we had a power failure.

description.romaji: Expresses the speaker's conjecture about past actions or events based on reliable information.
description.kanji: Expresses the speaker's conjecture about past actions or events based on reliable information.

examples.romaji: Kinō no arashi de gyosen ga shizunda rashii desu.
examples.kanji: 昨日[きのう]の 嵐[あらし]で 漁[ぎょ]船[せん]が沈[しず]んだらしいです。
examples.translation: I heard that a fishing boat sank due to yesterday's storm.

examples.romaji: Tomu wa sensei ni shikarareta rashii.
examples.kanji: トムは 先[せん]生[せい]に叱[しか]られたらしい。
examples.translation: It seems that Tom was scolded by his teacher.

examples.romaji: Miki-san wa demo (kōshin) ni sanka shita rashii desu.
examples.kanji: 三[み]木[き]さんはデモ（ 行[こう]進[しん]）に参[さん]加[か]したらしいです。
examples.translation: It looks like Mr. Miki participated in the demonstration (parade).

conjugation.translation:
• "I hear that ~"
  • "I heard that ~"
  • "People say that ~"

description.romaji: Expresses hearsay about past actions or events.
description.kanji: Expresses hearsay about past actions or events.

examples.romaji: Kyūshū de kinō yuki ga futta sō da.
examples.kanji: 九[きゅう]州[しゅう]で 昨日[きのう]雪[ゆき]が降[ふ]ったそうだ。
examples.translation: I hear that it snowed in Kyushu yesterday.

examples.romaji: Akiko-san ni onna no akachan ga umareta sō desu.
examples.kanji: 秋[あき]子[こ]さんに 女[おんな]の 赤[あか]ちゃんが生[う]まれたそうです。
examples.translation: I heard that a baby girl was born to Akiko.

examples.romaji: Hawai de mata kazan ga bakuhatsu shita sō da.
examples.kanji: ハワイでまた 火[か]山[ざん]が爆[ばく]発[はつ]したそうだ。
examples.translation: People say that a volcano erupted again in Hawaii.

description.romaji: Expresses uncertainty about past actions or events.
description.kanji: Expresses uncertainty about past actions or events.

examples.romaji: Ano ko wa neru mae ni ha o migaita kashira/kana.
examples.kanji: あの 子[こ]は 寝[ね]る 前[まえ]に 歯[は]を磨[みが]いたかしら・かな。
examples.translation: I wonder if the child brushed his teeth before going to bed.

examples.romaji: Kare wa seifu kara hojokin ga moraetakashira/kana.
examples.kanji: 彼[かれ]は 政[せい]府[ふ]から 補[ほ]助[じょ]金[きん]が貰[もら]えたかしら・かな。
examples.translation: I wonder if he could get a grant from the government.

examples.romaji: Kanojo wa daigaku no nyūgaku shiken ni gōgaku shita kashira/kana.
examples.kanji: 彼[かの]女[じょ]は 大[だい]学[がく]の 入[にゅう]学[がく]試[し]験[けん]に合[ごう]格[がく]したかしら・かな。
examples.translation: I wonder if she passed the entrance examination for the university.

description.romaji: Indicates that the already existing state the subject is in remains unchanged.
description.kanji: Indicates that the already existing state the subject is in remains unchanged.

examples.romaji: Kare wa bōshi o kabutta mama heya ni haitta.
examples.kanji: 彼[かれ]は 帽[ぼう]子[し]をかぶったまま 部[へ]屋[や]に 入[はい]った。
examples.translation: He entered the room with his hat on.

examples.romaji: Atsui kara mado o aketa mama neta.
examples.kanji: 暑[あつ]いから 窓[まど]を開[あ]けたまま 寝[ね]た。
examples.translation: Because it was warm, I slept leaving the windows open.

examples.romaji: Gakusei wa kiritsu shita mama sensei no hanashi o kikimashita.
examples.kanji: 学[がく]生[せい]は起[き]立[りつ]したまま 先[せん]生[せい]の 話[はなし]を 聞[き]きました。
examples.translation: Students listened to the teacher's speech while standing.

description.romaji: Indicates that an action or event takes place after another action or event has taken place.
description.kanji: Indicates that an action or event takes place after another action or event has taken place.

examples.romaji: Honda-san wa Kanada kara modotta ato de byōki ni narimashita.
examples.kanji: 本[ほん]田[だ]さんはカナダから戻[もど]ったあとで 病[びょう]気[き]になりました。
examples.translation: Miss Honda became ill after she came back from Canada.

examples.romaji: Kono futatsu o yoku kurabeta ato de kochira ni kimeta.
examples.kanji: この 二[ふた]つをよく比[くら]べたあとでこちらに 決[き]めた。
examples.translation: After comparing these two thoroughly, I decided on this one.

examples.romaji: Kare wa kyō no ka o fukushū shita ato de ashita no ka o yoshū shimasu.
examples.kanji: 彼[かれ]は 今日[きょう]の 課[か]を復[ふく]習[しゅう]したあとで 明日[あした]の 課[か]を 予[よ]習[しゅう]します。
examples.translation: He prepares tomorrow's lessons after reviewing today's lessons.

description.romaji: Indicates when an action or event took place.
description.kanji: Indicates when an action or event took place.

examples.romaji: Shōnen wa saifu o hirotta toki (ni) sugu keisatsu ni todokemashita.
examples.kanji: 少[しょう]年[ねん]は 財[さい]布[ふ]を拾[ひろ]った時[とき]（に）すぐ 警[けい]察[さつ]に 届[とど]けました。
examples.translation: When the boy picked up the wallet, he took it to the police immediately.

examples.romaji: Watashi-tachi ga Doitsu ni ita toki (ni) chōnan ga umareta.
examples.kanji: 私[わたし]達[たち]がドイツにいた時[とき](（に） 長[ちょう]男[なん]が 生[う]まれた。
examples.translation: While we were in Germany, our eldest son was born.

examples.romaji: Basu ga densha ni shōtotsu shita toki (ni) ōku no hito ga shibō shimashita.
examples.kanji: バスが 電[でん]車[しゃ]に衝[しょう]突[とつ]した時[とき]（に） 多[おお]くの 人[ひと]が 死[し]亡[ぼう]しました。
examples.translation: When a bus collided with a train, many people died.

description.romaji: Used as a modifier of the following noun, e.g. kinō kita hito (a person who came yesterday); watashi ga yonda hon (the book which I read).
description.kanji: Used as a modifier of the following noun, e.g. 昨日[きのう]来[き]た 人[ひと] (a person who came yesterday); 私[わたし]が 読[よ]んだ 本[ほん] (the book which I read).

examples.romaji: Chichi ga tsutta sakana o tabeta.
examples.kanji: 父[ちち]が釣[つ]った魚[さかな]を 食[た]べた。
examples.translation: We ate the fish that our father caught.

examples.romaji: Kinō oboeta kanji o wasurete shimatta.
examples.kanji: 昨日[きのう]覚[おぼ]えた漢[かん]字[じ]を 忘[わす]れてしまった。
examples.translation: I forgot (to my regret) the kanji that I memorized yesterday.

examples.romaji: Kono kikai o hatsumei shita hito ga kaijō ni kite imasu.
examples.kanji: この 機[き]械[かい]を発[はつ]明[めい]した人[ひと]が 会[かい]場[じょう]に 来[き]ています。
examples.translation: The person who invented this machine is in the assembly hall.

description.romaji: Expresses two past actions or events in one sentence.
description.kanji: Expresses two past actions or events in one sentence.

examples.romaji: Kare wa kusa o katta bakari de naku umi e kodomo o tsureteitta.*
examples.kanji: 彼[かれ]は 草[くさ]を刈[か]ったばかりでなく 海[うみ]へ 子[こ]供[ども]を 連[つ]れて 行[い]った。＊
examples.translation: He not only mowed the grass but also took his children to the ocean.

footnotes.romaji: *Tsureteiku is a compound verb made up of tsureru (take) and iku (go). This is used for animate things. For inanimate things, motteiku is used. These verbs conjugate like the verb iku.
footnotes.kanji: *連[つ]れて 行[い]く is a compound verb made up of 連[つ]れる (take) and 行[い]く (go). This is used for animate things. For inanimate things, 持[も]って 行[い]く is used. These verbs conjugate like the verb 行[い]く.

examples.romaji: Arukisugite, ashi ga tsukareta bakari de naku nodo mo kawaita.
examples.kanji: 歩[ある]きすぎて、 足[あし]が疲[つか]れたばかりでなく 喉[のど]も 乾[かわ]いた。
examples.translation: I walked too much, so not only did my feet get tired, but I got thirsty.

examples.romaji: Jon wa Nihon no daigaku o sotsugyō shita bakari de naku Nihon no kaisha ni shūshoku shimashita.
examples.kanji: ジョンは 日[に]本[ほん]の 大[だい]学[がく]を卒[そつ]業[ぎょう]したばかりでなく 日[に]本[ほん]の 会[かい]社[しゃ]に 就[しゅう]職[しょく]しました。
examples.translation: John not only graduated from a Japanese university but also found a job at a Japanese company.

description.romaji: Expresses two or more past actions or events in one sentence.
description.kanji: Expresses two or more past actions or events in one sentence.

examples.romaji: Natsu ni wa yama ni mo nobotta shi, umi de mo oyoida.
examples.kanji: 夏[なつ]には 山[やま]にも登[のぼ]ったし、 海[うみ]でも 泳[およ]いだ。
examples.translation: I not only climbed a mountain but also swam in the ocean during the summer.

examples.romaji: Taifū de ie mo tsubureta shi, hashi mo nagaremashita.
examples.kanji: 台[たい]風[ふう]で 家[いえ]も潰[つぶ]れたし、 橋[はし]も 流[なが]れました。
examples.translation: Not only were houses destroyed by the typhoon but also bridges were washed away.

examples.romaji: Kyō wa sōji mo shita shi, sentaku mo shita shi, kaimono mo shita.
examples.kanji: 今日[きょう]は 掃[そう]除[じ]もしたし、 洗[せん]濯[たく]もしたし、 買[か]い 物[もの]もした。
examples.translation: Today I cleaned house, washed clothes, and did some shopping.

description.romaji: Expresses a condition.
description.kanji: Expresses a condition.

examples.romaji: Jikan ga attara asobi ni kite kudasai.
examples.kanji: 時[じ]間[かん]があったら遊[あそ]びに 来[き]てください。
examples.translation: If there's time, please come to visit me.

examples.romaji: Mō sukoshi yasetara kono sukāto ga hakeru.
examples.kanji: もう 少[すこ]し痩[や]せたらこのスカートがはける。
examples.translation: If I lose a little more weight, I can wear this skirt.

examples.romaji: Dare ka hana o mottekitara*, kono kabin ni ikete kudasai.
examples.kanji: だれか 花[はな]を持[も]って 来[き]たら*、この 花[か]びんに 生[い]けてください。
examples.translation: If someone brings some flowers, please arrange them in this vase.

description.romaji: Indicates that the action or event in the subordinate clause (the tara-clause) takes place before the action or event in the main clause.
description.kanji: Indicates that the action or event in the subordinate clause (the たら-clause) takes place before the action or event in the main clause.

examples.romaji: Eki ni tsuitara densha ga deta tokoro deshita.
examples.kanji: 駅[えき]に着[つ]いたら電[でん]車[しゃ]が 出[で]たところでした。
examples.translation: When I arrived at the station, (I found that) the train had just left.

examples.romaji: Rokuji o sugitara uchi e kaeranakereba naranai.
examples.kanji: 六[ろく]時[じ]を過[す]ぎたらうちへ 帰[かえ]らなければならない。
examples.translation: When it's six o'clock, I must go home.

examples.romaji: Kono shigoto o kansei shitara, Hawai e iku tsumori desu.
examples.kanji: この 仕[し]事[ごと]を完[かん]成[せい]したら、ハワイへ 行[い]くつもりです。
examples.translation: I intend to go to Hawaii after completing this work.

description.romaji: Expresses a suggestion or proposal in casual conversation.
description.kanji: Expresses a suggestion or proposal in casual conversation.

examples.romaji: Kono kēki o futatsu ni kittara.
examples.kanji: このケーキを 二[ふた]つに切[き]ったら。
examples.translation: How about cutting this cake in two?

examples.romaji: Mō iranai (no) nara sutetara.
examples.kanji: もう 要[い]らない（の）なら捨[す]てたら。
examples.translation: If you don't need it anymore, why not throw it away?

examples.romaji: Sono shoku ni ōboshitara.
examples.kanji: その 職[しょく]に応[おう]募[ぼ]したら。
examples.translation: Why not apply for that job?

conjugation.translation:
• "do things like ~ and ~"
  • "sometimes do ~ and sometimes do ~"

description.romaji: Expresses an alternative or an indefinite number of actions or events in no particular sequence. A single action or event may be listed as a representative of others (Example 3).
description.kanji: Expresses an alternative or an indefinite number of actions or events in no particular sequence. A single action or event may be listed as a representative of others (Example 3).

examples.romaji: Pātī de nondari tabetari odottari shita.
examples.kanji: パーティーで飲[の]んだり食[た]べたり踊[おど]ったりした。
examples.translation: We did things like drinking, eating, and dancing at the party.

examples.romaji: Watashi-tachi wa sensei ni homeraretari shikararetari shimasu.
examples.kanji: 私[わたし]達[たち]は 先[せん]生[せい]に誉[ほ]められたり叱[しか]られたりします。
examples.translation: Sometimes we are praised and sometimes scolded by our teachers.

examples.romaji: Natsu ni wa tozan shitari suru.
examples.kanji: 夏[なつ]には登山[とざん]したりする。
examples.translation: In summer I do things like mountain climbing.

description.romaji: Expresses a pair of opposite actions or events.
description.kanji: Expresses a pair of opposite actions or events.

examples.romaji: Watashi wa asa kōhī o nondari nomanakattari suru.
examples.kanji: 私[わたし]は 朝[あさ]コーヒーを飲[の]んだり 飲[の]まなかったりする。
examples.translation: Sometimes I drink coffee in the morning and sometimes I don't.

examples.romaji: Tenki ni yotte Fuji-san ga mietari mienakattari shimasu.
examples.kanji: 天[てん]気[き]によって 富[ふ]士[じ]山[さん]が見[み]えたり 見[み]えなかったりします。
examples.translation: Sometimes Mt. Fuji can be seen and sometimes it can't be seen, depending on the weather.

examples.romaji: Kinyōbi ni wa Kimura-san wa kitari konakattari shimasu.
examples.kanji: 金[きん]曜[よう]日[び]には 木[き]村[むら]さんは来[き]たり 来[こ]なかったりします。
examples.translation: On Fridays, Mr. Kimura sometimes comes and sometimes he doesn't.
